NB: There is a (nominalizing) suffix -m 'which refers to a place, an instrument, or a tense-marked event. It is used for specific events with known participants. It does not occur by itself but is found in combinations with temporal elements, namely -a-m 'future place or means', 'aim', -mu-m 'past place or means', 'past infinitive' and -pe-ye-m 'usual place or means' (Adelaar with Muysken 2004:529, referring to Smeets 1989:263-71).

Temporal reference in the past is not marked on the verb, and does not have to be marked in a special way. Past temporal reference can optionally be expressed by means of a number of particles; they can occur everywhere in the clause but the ultimate position (cf. Sakel 2003:286).

comment: N.B. In Mamaind, a closely related Northern Nambikwaran language, there are nominal temporal suffixes which encode past and future distinctions. These suffixes are not related to tense markers on the verb (cf. Eberhard 2009:343). See also Lowe (1999:282) for nominal temporal suffixes in the Namb.family (in Dixon & Aikhenvald (1999) The Amazonian languages).
Nominalizers can encode TAM (cf. Fleck 2003:304, 292)
There are deictic forms with semantics 'present' and 'absent' which seem to be able to encode tense distinctions.
The morphemes can also co-occur on personal pronouns and on the subordinate marker tox (cf. Terraza 2009:80).

Everett & Kern (1997:153) mention with regard to demonstratives in Wari': There are three temporal demonstratives that distinguish how long the person or thing referred to has been absent: paca' 'that just occurred (always heard but never seen)', cara ne 'that recently absent', and cara pane 'that long absent'. It is hard to say whether ne and pane are actually part of the demonstrative. We have included them because they always accompany cara when used as a demonstrative (cara also occurs as a postverbal modifier, meaning 'always' or 'forever'). Ne and pane are sentence-final temporal particles ('recent past' and 'remote past' respectively).
Certainty: ?

There is a set of deictic classifiers in Pilag (na' 'coming/prox', so' 'going away/past', ga' 'absent/distal') which seem to be able to convey the meaning of a past tense (having either a NP scope, or a propositional scope) (cf. Vidal 2001:113,343).
Certainty: ?

There are probably no demonstratives which are used within the NP (the forms which are regarded as 'demonstratives' in Sakel (2004) only encode gender distinction; it is not clear from their properties if they can be treated as demonstratives on par with other languages. There are only adverbial demonstrative forms which encode distance.
NB: Demonstrative forms can be used adnominally when they are relativized.
kistus karin ; esta ropa
Dickinson (2002:53) notes that demonstratives most often precede the head noun, while the other modifiers within the NP show various behavior.
Almost always precedes, the order head-DEM is emphatic (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:92)

The demonstratives occur preceding the head noun and before the numeral in the noun phrase. They take a noun classifier when preceding or replacing inanimate, countable nouns. They can and most frequently do occur without the noun (Miller 1999:5).

Demonstrative pronouns can function as adnominal demonstratives if the head noun is followed by a definite marker. Dem.pronouns precede the noun in that case (cf. Everett 2006:315). It is not clear whether the whole set of demonstrative pronouns can be used adnominally.

Noun modifiers, possessives, demonstratives, numerals beyond 'two' and often numeral 'one': obligatorily precede the head. Adjectives, numeral 'two' and relative clauses may precede or follow the head noun without any obvious semantic changes (cf. Valenzuela 2003:235).
Demonstratives 'usually precede the head and follow it only if the prehead position is occupied by an interrogative modifier in an interrogative clause' (Aikhenvald 2003:562).
Demonstratives, however, can occur after the head noun in possessive constructions (e.g.: 3-brother DEM 'that brother') (cf. Fernndez Garay 1998:232).
Guirardello (1999:29) mentions that not all speakers like the use of demonstratives as modifiers and prefer the pronominal use of demonstrative forms.
Demonstratives are rather NPs forming an opposition to a head noun ('this dog' is really 'this one the dog') (S.Meira, p.c.)

Demonstratives, numerals, and possessor obligatorily occur in prenominal position. Most relative clauses (which are nominalizations) occur in prenominal position, while most property concepts occur in postnominal position (cf. Olawsky 2006:329-330).
Both word orders are possible, though postceding is reported to be most widely spread (cf. Romero-Figeroa 1997:51)
NB: There is one demonstrative form in Mamaind, which is realized as a suffix (cf. Eberhard 2009:343).
The only possible (van Gijn 2006, p.c. 26.05.10)
Nominalization of verbs in M. occurs by means of tonal morphemes, a different tonal morpheme marks subordinate clauses (relative and adverbial clauses) (cf. Seifart 2005:39,71).
Subordinate clause markers are used (cf. Guillaume 2008:85).
isnapunqui u uricuspa 'te fuiste sin avisarme
There is a set of adverbial subordinators which are used to form adverbial clauses (see Vallejos 2010:615).
The nominalizing suffix is usually an inanimate nominalizer. 'However, some adverbial clauses are formed with nominalizing suffixes which agree with the subject of the clause' (M&M 1999:147)
Adverbial clauses take deverbalizing (nominalizing?) suffixes and additional morphology (cf. Miller 1999:139, 150)

Comment from Pattie: 'Most of the adverbializing morphology doesn't clearly involve nominalization - in a couple of cases the morphemes have other functions associated with nouns, but not really as nominalizers (except possible the Dependent marker -Vp).'

purpose clauses yes
Numerals can also follow the head noun (Overall 2007:164).

Numerals may precede or follow the head depending on whether the reference is definite or indefinite. Numerals occur before the noun when the reference is indefinite, and after the noun when reference is definite (cf. Frank 1990:31) (see Cubeo (Tucanoan), and Chibchan languages of Costa Rica where definiteness correlates with the order of adjective/noun).
NB: Numerals in Karo are constituents of adverbial phrases and not of the noun phrases (cf. Gabas 1999:51,135). Example of adverbial use of numeral 'two' is on p.173.
Word order: modifier-noun: 93% and noun-modifier: 7% (F.Seifart, p.c.; the counting was done by Borislava Ilcheva & Elisabeth Oner (University of Regensburg).
Numerals other than '1' are compounds followed by the nominalizer -di (cf. Crowell 1979:218)
Numerals belong to the adjective class 1 'right-bound roots'; they occur preceding the head noun within an NP (cf. Danielsen 2007:168).
Certainty: ?
suu muruymi jachani 'dos hijos tengo'
However, when the modifier represents new information to the hearers, it is more likely to occur postnominally (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:92).

'Numerals usually occur before the head noun, or follow the head noun and precede the classifier.' When numerals are in the same noun phrase with demonstratives, they follow the demonstrative. With animate nouns, the numerals often follow the head noun; the numerals carry the gender or class suffix that agrees with the noun. (Miller 1999:4). See Miller (1999:46) for additional info.
only numbers 1 and 2 are EseEjja
Numerals are more often used as adverbs.
The word order numeral-noun is preferred with native numerals 'one' and 'two', whereas with borrowed Spanish forms the order is reversed (Mily Crevels, p.c.).
Native 'numbers'  are 1 and 2, other numbers are loans from Portuguese. They are verbs and seem to be used as predicates only  (cf. Dixon 2004:559).
The order N-num is also possible but much less common (cf. Epps 2008:314)
Numerals are reported to belong to the class of adverbs; nevertheless, (few) examples are available with seemingly attributive use.
Numerals used with nouns precede the head. If a numeral is used with a plural personal pronouns then it follows the pronoun (cf. Curnow 1997:90).
Numeral 'one' can occur in either order, while other numerals occur always before the head noun.

Native numerals are verbs, which occur with a classifier prefixed to the verbal root thus substituting the noun (cf. Telles 2002:191, 315-317).

In Fleck (2003) examples are found with both prenominal and postnominal use of numerals (cf. Fleck 2003:558). Loos (1999:235, in Dixon and Aikhenvald, eds) a schematic position of modifiers in Panoan languages is given with numerals shown to occur post-head.

Grondona (1998:91) notes that Mocov seems to lack numeral forms, and has borrowed all its numerals from Spanish. The Q of word order of numeral-noun is answered on basis of word order of quantifier and Spanish numerals used in the NP.
Concluded from examples (cf. Terraza 2009:85,94).
Construction of a compounding (?). The relative word order of numeral and noun is concluded on basis of example (195) (see Haude 2006:115).
'Numerals appear in verbal position with the syntax of intransitive verbs' (Everett & Kern 1997:348).

NB: there seem to be no native numerals in Pilag. The numeral forms onole/onolek 'one.F/M' and dosolqa 'two' are borrowings from Spanish which have been morphologically and phonologically adapted into the language, while the rest of the numerals borrowed without any morph. or phonol. adaptations.

Numerals are expressed by verbal roots which receive the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (have exactly the same construction as with verbal roots expressing property concepts) (cf. Girn 2008:297). Concluded from examples that the most common word order is NUM-NOUN, whereas NOUN-ADJ (despite that constructions with numerals and property concepts seem to be structurally similar).
ishkay kimsa muyu-n 'dos tres veces'

comment: Some examples have `also` but most sources give one single question word,

Adjectives always follow the head noun (Overall 2007:252). Modification within the NP is relatively uncommon in texts, adjectives instead typically function predicatively. [...]When it does occur, however, attributive adjectival modification can be quite elaborate  (Overall 2007:252).

There seem to be little evidence for adjectival modification within the NP (predominantly predicative modification, where property concepts are expressed by intransitive verbs with pronominal marker encoding the notional subject). The only example with a possible instance of modification is: suto  here-ro  apo-pe [woman  be.pretty-3F.O  arrive-PFTV] 'The woman who's pretty has arrived' (p.563). Info on the Q 'Is there a separate class of adjectives?': Property concepts are expressed either by classificatory nouns or by intransitive verbs with the notional subject encoded by either subject or object pronominal markers (hareka-no [be.good-1SG.O] 'I am good' (p.281), uwa kuwu mita-ru [3SG.M  head.of  be.big-M.O] 'Its/his head is big' (p.449) (cf. Facundes 2000:281). Certainty: ?
Adjectives follow the head noun (cf. Frank 1990:4,32). Rather than occurring alone most adjectives occur with kawa 'seem' in an adjective phrase.
but Poss Pssd A

Adjectival meanings are expressed by relative clauses (cf. Seifart 2005:51). Word order: modifier-noun: 93% and noun-modifier: 7% (F.Seifart, p.c.; the counting was done by Borislava Ilcheva & Elisabeth Oner (University of Regensburg).

Property concepts are expressed by verbs by means of a relative clause construction (cf. Nonato 2008:34). Crowell (1979:26) notes that relative clauses may follow the noun 'only if the verb of the clause is an adjectival one'. Certainty: ?

Modification within NP is not very common in general in Baure (cf. Danielsen 2007:168). The preference for a particular word order of adjective and head noun depends on the kind of adjective:  adjectives of 'class III: derived forms' which constitute the largest part of the adjective class are mainly post-nominal (13 cases out of 14); adjectives of 'absolute class II' (which do not get classifier incorporated, and whose forms remain unchanged) are predominantly adnominal (32 cases out of 50); adjectives of 'class I: right-bound roots' (denoting dimension, and used with classifiers) are postnominal (3 cases out of 3) (cf. Danielsen 2007:168).
Sakel (2003:82) notes that there is a tendency that modifiers appear after the head noun with animate heads, and before the head noun with inanimate heads.
chujkuni laja ; hombre flaco
Property concepts are expresed by nominalized verbs (see Vallejos 2010:418).
Underived adjectives, 'pseudo-adjectives' i.e. lake 'yellow', and nouns functioning as modifiers are always pre-head.
Certainty: ?

'When the modifier represents new information to the hearers, it is more likely to occur postnominally' (M&M 1999:92). The order seems also to depend on the type of noun (a mass noun, etc. ), see Morse & Maxwell (1999:128).

The descriptive modifier generally precedes the head noun in the NP. When it goes before the head, it is marked with a deverbalizer but not with a class or gender marker. It follows the head noun when a demonstrative, number [OK: numeral], or genitive precedes the nouns. Following the noun, the deverbalized modifier is inflected with the noun class or gender marker, or the noun is repeated if it does not have a separate class marker. (Miller 1999:3).

NB: The category closest to adjectives which F.Rose calls 'attributives' cannot occur with a noun directly but need a relativizer. Thus, they can be used attributively only when part of a relative clause. The head noun can precede, follow or be internal to the modifying relative clause (cf. Rose 2003:218, p.c. 23.03.2011).
In reality it is kind of copula construction, since there no adjectives
Property concepts are expressed by verbs (cf. Martins 2004:221).
Adj- N. However, when a Spanish adjective is used, the order of constituents can be N-adj, esp.if the noun is also a loan (cf. Curnow 1997:119)

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: concluded from example (van de Kerke 2009:302)

Adjectives must follow the head noun (cf. Fleck 2003:466). See Loos (1999:235) in Amazonian Languages on the occurence and adjs before or after the head in Panoan languages and the semantic effects as result.

Property concepts are expressed by stative verbs in Wich; the issue of attributive use of these verbs remains to be studied further (cf. Terraza 2009:262). Vernica Nercesian (p.c. via Rik van Gijn) notes that for a property concept to be used attributively, it has to be turned into a relative clause.

Adjectives used attributively are found either as part of a compound or as the predicate in a relative clause (cf. Haude 2006:114). The relative word order of adjective and noun in a compound is always adj-N (cf. Haude 2006:115).

NB: Attributive modification is handled like a possessive phrase: the first syntactically nominal element occurs with a genitive morpheme (nominal inflectional clitic or suffix) and is understood as modifying the second noun. These genitive nominal elements can have the form of derived nouns or -xi' nouns (Everett & Kern 1997:336). E.g. wijima-in xirim [smallness-3n house] 'small house' (lit: 'the house's smallness') (Everett & Kern 1997:151,336).
Vidal (2001:293) notes that adjectives always follow the noun they modify. If an adjective precedes the noun, then it functions as a predicate and is not part of the same NP with the noun.

Property concepts are mainly expressed by verbal roots which receive the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (cf. Girn 2008:167,233) which is used to mark relative clauses (cg. Girn 2008:407). Numerals are expressed by verbal roots which receive the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (have exactly the same construction as with verbal roots expressing property concepts) (cf. Girn 2008:297). Concluded from examples that the most common word order is NOUN-ADJ, whereas NUM-NOUN (despite that constructions with numerals and property concepts seem to be structurally similar).
sabida kumadre, atoq malino-qa

Property concepts are expressed by verbs; when functioning as attributive modifiers, the construction of a relative clause is used: dog (REL.marker to.be.nice) 'dog which is nice'  (cf. Alves 2004:50,58).

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: In order to function as modifiers within an NP property concepts (which are actually verbs) must be nominalized with the attributive suffix -ta. The word order is N-nominalized.verb (cf. Araujo 2004:161-2).
The word pata 'big, old, important' precedes the noun it modifies when it refers to the size; however, it follows the head noun when it refers to the age.

When a noun is combined with two adjectives, the preferred order is adj-N-adj (see p. 241). Noun modifiers, possessives, demonstratives, numerals beyond 'two' and often numeral 'one': obligatorily precede the head. Adjectives, numeral 'two' and relative clauses may precede or follow the head noun without any obvious semantic changes (cf. Valenzuela 2003:235).
Adjectives usually precede the head if the head is specific and/or definite (cf.Aikhenvald 2003:562).
Property concepts are expressed by stative verbs, which seem to receive a nominalizing suffix -n when modifying a noun.

Gonzlez (2005:128) notes that Tapiete does not have a clear lexical category adjective. Instead, adjectives share with inactive verbs a number of verbal morphological features such as the set of person markers, aspect, as well as derivational morphology as the nominalizing suffix -wa ~ -a 'NMLZ'.
Property concepts are actually adverbs, in order to refer to a noun they have to be nominalized first (Meira, p.c.)

NB: There are no underived adjectives; the words which have function usually assigned to adjectives can be devided into noun-like and verb-like. Therefore, the position is not homogeneous: some occur only postnominally (this is the unmarked variant), while others can occur prenominally and postnominally (cf. Olawsky 2006:308).

Adjectival concepts are expressed by verbs. These take the same morphology as verbs and behave like intransitive verbs in in the language. Such verbal roots are not found on their own to modify a noun (Eberhard 2009:364).
Semantic adj-s are expressed by nominalized verbs
Example 333 on p.69
NB: Adjectives are almost exclusively used predicatively (van Gijn 2006:92, p.c. 26.05.10)
While adjectives always follow the head noun, relative clauses typically follow the noun but may precede it as well (Overall 2007:252).
Instances of relative clauses preceding the head noun are very rare, though present in data (cf. Frank 1990:5)
relative clause formation?
Word order: noun-rel.clause: 70% and rel.clause-noun: 30% (F.Seifart, p.c.; the counting was done by Borislava Ilcheva & Elisabeth Oner (University of Regensburg).
Crowell (1979:26) notes that relative clauses may follow the noun 'only if the verb of the clause is an adjectival one. Otherwise it must precede the noun'.

Relative clauses are characterized by a nominalized predicate, and generally follow the noun (comparable to the behaviour of modifying adj-s of class III 'which are frequently nominalized forms, marked by -no 'nom1', one of the nominalizers used in relative clauses' (Danielsen 2007:171).

Verbal relative clauses tend to occur after the head noun; a number of copula relative clauses, notably demonstrative RC (there are no nominal demonstratives in Cavinea) and interrogative RC, only occur preposed to the head noun (cf. Guillaume 2008:406).
k'atu juphu khapa ; pueblo escarpado
Dickinson (2002:73) mentions that in elicitation the most common word order is the relative clause preceding the head, while in texts, the reverse order is also encountered.

'Relative clauses are either postnominal, or more commonly, appear in a noun phrase without any overt head noun. In the latter case, they can equally well be considered as noun phrases which happen to be headed by a nominalized verb. The nominalized verb is always clause final in the relative clause, and takes any case marking imposed by the independent clause. If the NP being modified by a relative clause is headed by an overt noun, both the head noun and the verb of the relative clause will then be case marked. This implies that a relative clause modifying an overt noun appears in an appositive structure'.  (Morse & Maxwell 1999:151).

The word order headnoun-rel.clause is general, except if the headnoun is a demonstrative, or if the relative clause is internally headed (only found with the use of a relative clause construction to make an adjective into a nominal modifier  (cf. Rose 2003:218).
Mortensen (1999:11,128): internally headed relative clauses. 'The best evidence of this is that case markers applied to the modified noun are suffixed onto the end of the relative clause'.
Nominalized VP preceding the head (cf. Epps 2008:828)

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Exemple 450 suggests that relative clauses precede the head
cf. Fleck (2003:1020) for examples

The attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (which occurs on verbal roots to form attributives) is the morpheme to marks relative clauses. It can also be used to mark complement and adverbial clauses (cf. Girn 2008:405).
saqe-sqa-n qari 'the man they left behind'

mostly headless
Always posthead (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:562)

NB: use of demonstratives, numerals, adjectives, and relative clauses has the same syntactic pattern in the sense that they are all nominalizations and are loosely bound to the noun (bound only semantically) (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

Demonstratives, numerals, and possessor obligatorily occur in prenominal position. Most relative clauses (which are nominalizations) occur in prenominal position, while most property concepts occur in postnominal position (cf. Olawsky 2006:329-330).

comment: suffix rara on the adjective
Statistics given in Frank (1990:123): Out of 283 intransitive clauses, 200 clauses are subjectless, but all other have the SV word order.
Subject of an intransitive verb tends to follow the verb form, however, the other word order also occurs (cf. Smeets 2008:347-8).
in nominal predication clauses with a pronoun VS
Word order is relatively free, SOV the most frequent one, though OSV and SVO also occur (cf. Seifart 2005:68)

SV (S Danielsen, p.c. 20.05.2010). In narratives, examples with VOS word order is found esp. when human or animate argument is involved. For emphasis S precedes V, this is also the means of marking of the change of S (cf. Danielsen 2007:333). If S is expressed by a pronoun, the pronoun generally precedes the predicate: S-Pred-O.
fairly free,
nisi sekaimancha ; yo aprendera
word order is strict
However, different word order patterns correlate with tense and progressive aspect (see Vallejos 2010:466).
SV occurs as well, though less common (cf. M&M 1999:141)
'The basic constituent order in Desano is OV with the subject (S) generally preceding the verb (V) and the object/patient (O)' (Miller 1999:2)

Dixon (2004:86) mentions that '[m]ore than half the clauses in Jarawara texts are intransitive', and only about 3% of transitive clauses have both A and O stated. In such cases, in about 85% of the time the A precedes the O and about 73% of the time the O precedes the A. The order is not fixes and grammatically not significant (cf. Dixon 2004:86).
Topicalized subjects can occur before and after V (story)

'There is a strong tendency to have either a subject or object present, but not both'.Out of 714 sentences having transitive verbs, only 99 have both S and O (about 12%). 'Of these 99 cases, only 48 have SOV order.The total number of sentences in the corpus that are not consistent with SOV order is 160 (about 12%)'. Weber (1996:16) gives the following statistics: Out of 1309 sentences: intransitive sentences: 53% of the sentences with subject present (76% word order SV, 24% word order VS). Transitive sentences: 31% of the sentences with subject present (75% word order SV, 68% word order OV); 69% of the sentences with subject absent (71% word order OV). 'There is a strong tendency to have either a subject or object present, but not both.' (cf. Weber (1996:16) for more details).

comment: Concluded from examples (e.g. see p. 344)

Modification within the NP is relatively uncommon in texts, adjectives instead typically function predicatively. [...]When it does occur, however, attributive adjectival modification can be quite elaborate  (Overall 2007:252).

NB: Q answers as 'no' since there seems to be little evidence for adjectival modification within the NP (predominantly predicative modification, where property concepts are expressed by instransitive verbs with pronominal marker enconding the notional subject). The only example with a possible instance of modification is: ''

NB: In Karo, classifiers are not obligatory (if they occur they occur right after the classified noun), however, if they occur and if a noun is modified by an adjective, the classifier obligatorily occurs after the noun and after the adjective (in concord) (cf. Gabas 1999:176).  Adjectives in Karo always have to precede either by a noun or by a clitic pronoun (which can occur instead of the head noun) (cf. Gabas 1999:113).
only applies to full forms, not base forms
Property concepts are expressed by verbs by means of a relative clause construction (cf. Nonato 2008:34).

In modifying constructions with adjectives only the last element of the NP is marked for plural. When adjective is used predicativly then both adjective and noun can be marked for plural (cf. Danielsen 2007:132). Danielsen (2007:168) notes that '[m]odification within an NP is not very common in Baure in general', they are considerably more often used predicatively (see statistics: Danielsen 2007:168).

Plural marker is optional with all nouns. In case of plural NPs with overt plural marker, the plural marker is found cliticized to the property concept as it occurs after the head noun (e.g. cooking.pot big=PL 'cooking pots' (cf. Guillaume 2008:465)).
Not always, because not every adjective has a gender/number inflection

'Adj-s are inflected to agree in gender or classifier and number with the noun they modify (even if that noun is not overt)' (p.126). 'When an adjective modifies a noun, both the noun and the adjective take classifiers or gender markers. Usually, the clfs or gender markers on the adj and the noun are identical [...]. But sometimes they differ' (Morse & Maxwell 1999:123). Morse & Maxwell (1999:113) mention that when a multiword NP is marked by -RE (marking both direct and indirect objects),'the last word of the NP is always marked with -RE; preceding words in the phrase may or may not be so marked'.

The descriptive modifier generally precedes the head noun in the NP. When it goes before the head, it is marked with a deverbalizer but not with a class or gender marker. [...] Following the noun, the deverbalized modifier is inflected with the noun class or gender marker, or the noun is repeated if it does not have a separate class marker (Miller 1999:3). Property concepts are expressed by verbal roots occurring with classifying morphemes denoting shape (for inanimate referents) or classifying morphemes denoting masc sg, fem sg or plural (for animate referents) (Miller 1999:35). In case of inanimate nouns, the plural suffix (only -ri?) occurs on both the head noun and any modifier that accompany it (Miller 1999:52).

NB: The category closest to adjectives which F.Rose calls 'attributives' cannot occur with a noun directly but need a relativizer. Thus, they can be used attributively only when part of a relative clause. The head noun can precede, follow or be internal to the modifying relative clause (cf. Rose 2003:218, p.c. 23.03.2011).
Little use of adnominal adjectives

Moore (1984:145) mentions that '[s]ome adjective stems show no change in form whether they are singular or plural [...]. Others show differences in form due to suppletion, suffixation, or lack of stem formative final syllable lengthening'. Also that '[p]lural adjective stems can only modify plural nominals'. Certainty: ?
Not obligatory

NB: There is a closed class of 14 adjs. Two of these adjectives have distinct gender forms: bite/biti 'small' and one/owa 'another'. Besides this class of monomorphemic adjectives,  there is a small number of derived adj-s. Derived adj-s may function only as copula complements but not as modifiers within an NP (cf. Dixon 2004:337). Agreement within NP in Jarawara seems to be present only in possessive constructions: if 2 possessed nouns follow a 1/2 n.sg pronoun, each must be in a masc. form (see example p.340 + table 11.2). When a 1/2 n.sg pronoun is followed by a possessed noun and then an adjective, then the possessed noun is in masc. form but the adjective in in fem.form (see example p.341 + table 11.2). In possessive constructions: with alienable possession it is the possessed which determines the gender of an NP (for predicate agreement), and it is the possessor which determines the gender with inalienable possession (cf. Dixon 2004:280).

NB: Comments from Pattie: re quest.3.1.1 'Case-marker usually occurs at end of whole NP (so falls on the adj, which follows the N)'; regarding quest. 3.1.4. 'It's possible to use a classifier on both adj and N, but this isn't normally done and these may be acting simply as appositional NPs when it does happen'.
Property concepts are expressed by verbs (cf. Martins 2004:221).

'Em Kano, em geral, no âmbito do SN,  pode ocorrer acordo cruzada entre  alguns nomes morfologicamente marcados por classificadores nominais semanticamente transparentes e razes adjetivais, por incorporao do classificador':  atiti-tekwa uru-tekwa [rice-seed new (green)-seed] 'arroz novo, arroz verde' (l. Bacelar, p.c., email 13.01.2011).

All attributive modifiers agree with the noun in number and third person gender. This information must be expressed whether the noun appears overtly or not. comment: Cls are not always marked both on the adjective and the head noun (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:173-4).
Different from NP consisting of demonstrative and noun, there is no agreement in case between modifyng numeral and noun (Overall 2007:246).

Concluded from material
Numerals in Karo are constituents of adverbial phrases and not the noun phrases (cf. Gabas 1999:64,173). Example of adverbial use of numeral 'two' is on p.173.
only applies to full forms, not base forms
When nouns are modified by a numeral, there is no plural marker (this is also the case for human nouns), e.g. paerae w 'two sons' (cf. Sakel 2003:68).

In the Aymara varieties spoken in La Paz and Puno, plural marker is obligatorily absent when a noun is modified by a numeral. In Aymara varieties spoken in Moquegua, there is optional agreement between numeral and noun in the NP (Matt Coler, p.c.).

Agreement in noun class is obligatory only with numerals for 'one' and 'two'; with 'three' and higher agreement in noun class and additional number marker is optional. With the numeral  'two', the dual number marker is used instead of the plural marker. Also it should be noted that the plural marker used with numerals is a different morpheme from the plural marker  used in pronominal expressions (cf. Seifart 2005:130).

See example (39) on p.131 of numeral+noun NP, where number is marked only at the phrase level. Danielsen (2007:168) notes that '[m]odification within an NP is not very common in Baure in general', they are considerably more often used predicatively (see statistics: Danielsen 2007:168). Numerals belong to the class I adjectives ('right-bound roots') and are used with classifiers. There are only three numerals, they have to occur with a classifier; numerals above three are borrowed from Spanish, these can receive cls as well. The root 'other' is also member of this class and also receives cls.  (cf. Danielsen 2007:159).

The cardinal numeral 'one'  is marked for gender (either masculine or feminine), the rest of the cardinal numeral are not marked for gender (with one exception: in higher numbers which contain numeral 1, like 21, only the feminine form jiris exists and is used with both feminine and masculine nouns (cf. Sakel 2003:134). The ordinal numerals all have gender marking (cf. Sakel 2003:70). When nouns are modified by a numeral, there is no plural marker (this is also the case for human nouns), e.g. paerae w 'two sons' (cf. Sakel 2003:68).
There are examples of [num-noun-PL] NPs (ex.13.78d), however it should not be considered as agreement; besides, plural markers are optional with all nouns (cf. Guillaume 2008:480).
There are two native numerals, one and two, and the number for 'two' agrees in gender with the referent noun

Besides the features number, gender and phys. prop. : Morse & Maxwell (1999:113) mention that when a multiword NP is marked by -RE (marking both direct and indirect objects),'the last word of the NP is always marked with -RE; preceding words in the phrase may or may not be so marked'.

'Numerals usually occur before the head noun, or follow the head noun and precede the classifier. [...] With animate nouns, the numerals often follow the head noun; the numerals carry the gender or class suffix that agrees with the noun. (Miller 1999:4)

There is no agreement. Number marking on noun modified by a numeral higher than 2 is optional. Numeral one is normally accompanied by the particle -h 'only' which is suffixed either to the numeral or to a modified noun (cf. Rose 2003:216).
0 according to (Licht 1999:83-84)
They behave probably like adjectives
Native 'numbers'  are 1 and 2, other numbers are loans from Portuguese. They are verbs and seem to be used as predicates only  (cf. Dixon 2004:559).

NB: Numeral can take plural marker when the noun it occurs with is plural, however, in that case the numeral and the noun are best considered two appositional NPs (Epps 2008:314). 'Only for PNs/animates, esp. humans - inanimate Ns don't receive plural marking (animals do only optionally)' (Pattie Epps, p.c.). With regard to possible agreement in physical properties (involving a classifier): both numeral and noun can take a classifier but this is rare and probably involves apposition of two NPs rather than agreement within one NP (Pattie Epps, p.c.).
NB: Seki (2000:120) mentions that cardinal numerals behave as adverbs; however, there are examples of numerals used as modifiers of nouns (see example 309 on p.121).
Concluded from examples available (cf. Martins 2004:394)
Numerals may receive a gender marking suffix (-kw 'masc' and -nake 'fem' which can be used to specify gender of the head noun when used as modifiers of human nouns (cf. Bacelar 2004:114,156).

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Numerals are expressed by stative verbs in L. which occur with a classifier. Nouns to which classifier refers may be left out. Telles (2002:190) gives examples when numeral stems are used without a classifier but occur directly with imperfective markers.
Number marking on noun modified by a numeral is optional, it can be either singular or paucal or plural depending on the numeral (cf. Grondona 1998:91).
Certainty: ?
Construction of a compounding, see example (195) (Haude 2006:115).
Marked on the referent noun, not on the numeral. Number 'one' has also a plural inflection for 'few' (Luca Ciucci, p.c.).

'Numerals appear in verbal position with the syntax of intransitive verbs' . There is one compound verb that expresses the notion of cardinal numerals used as an attribute: xica' pe 'to be alone', used as 'one'. It is always used to express 'one', that is, the Portuguese numeral um is never used. There is another compound verb, tucu caracan 'to face each other', that used to be used as 'two' but is rarely used nowadays; rather the Portuguese numeral dois is used. Dois 'two' (masculine form of Portuguese 'two') is used irrespective of the gender of the noun it modifies. New numerals take the Portuguese form and occur as a simple verb' (Everett & Kern 1997:348).

NB: there are no native numerals in Pilag. The numeral forms onole/onolek 'one.F/M' and dosolqa 'two' are borrowings from Spanish which have been morphologically and phonologically adapted into the language, while the rest of the numerals borrowed without any morph. or phonol. adaptations.  Numeral dosolqa 'two' contains the morpheme -qa 'paucal' which also occurs on the noun modified by this numeral (cf. Vidal 2001:129). The statement on agreement is made on basis of these two numerals.

Concluded from available examples that there is agreement in number between head noun and numeral modifier: both constituents receive a plural marker (cf. Girn 2008:448,386); however, examples on p.402,372,389 with inanimate nouns modified by a numeral show no agreement and the numeral does not carry the attributive prefix -i which normally occurs on numerals (numerals are expressed by verbal roots, have exactly the same construction as with verbal roots expressing property concepts) (cf. Girn 2008:297).
Concluded from ex.373, cf. Cole (1982:94).
Example (539) p.86 shows modification of a noun by a numeral. Certainty: ?

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Ordinal and cardinal numerals are lacking in Saban. Speakers make use of verbal adverbs, such as amulu 'one/only/just' (another form is kata to express 'one'), bala 'dual', kata.bala or bala.amulu are used to indicate 'three'. All these forms are used predicatively (cf. Araujo 2004:96).
E.g. ~moni ~siitha-k [one bead-COL] 'one bead' (lit. 'one of the beads'), carekep mamo-k [two eye-INAN.PL] 'two eyes' (lit.'two of the eyes') (cf. Gmez 1990:74).
Valenzuela (2003:221) notes a case where both a quantifier and the head noun in the NP receive the plural marker (no obvious pause is heard between the two elements bearing the plural marker).
always apposition
Numerals 1-4 require noun class (classifier) agreement with head, the numeral 4 requires additionally agreement in plural marker (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:217).

NB: When a noun is modified by a numeral, it can optionally be marked for plural. It is more common to mark the noun in combination with a numeral for plural if it refers to a human. In contrast, if the noun modified by a numeral does not refer to a human, it is unlikely to be marked for plural (cf. Olawsky 2006:367).
Eberhard (2009:502) mentions that it is also common to use numerals as predicates, suffixed with inflectional verb morphology. Since numerals do occur as noun modifiers, the Q is not answered as n/a.

There is a subset of nouns which can trigger the use of collective marker on adjectives and numerals in a modifer function. Not clear enough on the moment whether it is derivation or agreement inflection (van Gijn p.c. 26.05.10).
only applies to full forms, not base forms

Agreement in noun class is obligatory only with numerals for 'one' and 'two'; with 'three' and higher agreement in noun class and additional number marker is optional. With the numeral  'two', the dual number marker is used instead of the plural marker. Also it should be noted that the plural marker used with numerals is a different morpheme from the plural marker  used in pronominal expressions (cf. Seifart 2005:130).
Both the numeral, which precedes the noun, and the noun receive a plural marker. Interestingly, in example (279) on p.91 the numeral and the noun receive different plural markers.
They behave probably like adjectives
Numerals occur with cls which are inherently sg or pl. (M.Crevels, p.c.)

comment: The noun is marked with plural

Numeral dosolqa 'two' contains the morpheme -qa 'paucal' which also occurs on the noun modified by this numeral (cf. Vidal 2001:129).

Number marking on the noun is not obligatory when it is modified by a numeral (cf. Cole 1982:128).

comment: Numerals 1-4 require noun class (classifier) agreement with head, the numeral 4 requires additionally agreement in plural marker (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:217).

The numeral for 'one' (ht-u 'one-M' /ht-o 'one-F') agrees in gender with the modifying noun (cf. Facundes 2000:359). The other native numeral epi 'two' shows no gender agreement (cf. Facundes 2000:359).
only applies to full forms, not base forms

Agreement in noun class is obligatory only with numerals for 'one' and 'two'; with 'three' and higher agreement in noun class and additional number marker is optional. With the numeral  'two', the dual number marker is used instead of the plural marker. Also it should be noted that the plural marker used with numerals is a different morpheme from the plural marker  used in pronominal expressions (cf. Seifart 2005:130).

The cardinal numeral 'one'  is marked for gender (either masculine or feminine), the rest of the cardinal numeral are not marked for gender. The ordinal numerals all have gender marking (cf. Sakel 2003:70).
There are two native numerals, one and two, and the number for 'two' agrees in gender with the referent noun

Masc/fem gender is realized for single number only and only on animate nouns (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:77). Therefore, on numerals gender is realized only on numeral 'one', as other numerals would require the use of the plural.animate suffix as agreement.
Only with numeral for 'one': fem.sg distinction (M.Crevels p.c.)

comment: Gender realized by classifying morphemes. See also examples of discontinuous NPs page 480.

Numerals receive a morpheme n when used as modifiers of feminine nouns, occur unmarked when used with masculine or neuter nouns. Numeral xawke 'two' has a separate form xa:one~xaone used for nouns which are feminine (cf. Fernndez Garay 1998:243).

Agreement in noun class is obligatory only with numerals for 'one' and 'two'; with 'three' and higher agreement in noun class and additional number marker is optional. With the numeral  'two', the dual number marker is used instead of the plural marker. Also it should be noted that the plural marker used with numerals is a different morpheme from the plural marker  used in pronominal expressions (cf. Seifart 2005:130).
NB: however, numeral for 'three' requires the use of a classifier due to its specific morphological properties (see ex. on p. 124).
Numerals occur with cls which encode physical characteristics, posture, animacy, cls are also inherently sg or pl. (M.Crevels, p.c.)

comment: Numerals 1-4 require noun class (classifier) agreement with head, the numeral 4 requires additionally agreement in plural marker (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:217).
NB: there is agreement in case between demonstrative and noun (Overall 2007:246).
Constructions with demonstratives modying a noun have a structure of a compound (cf. Tripp 1997:54).
only applies to full forms, not base forms

When plural noun is modified by a demonstrative, the plural marker occurs on the noun only. Demonstrative can receive the plural marking also if the head noun is omitted. E.g.: aw kare [aw karo e = this fish PL] 'these fishes', awge [aw ge = this PL] 'these ones' (cf. Nonato 2008:53).

Gender is not formally expressed on the noun, but is realized by agreement in cross-referencing clitics, and personal, possessive and demonstrative pronouns (only in the 3sg). 'Gender is an inherent catagory in Baure, and it is mainly biological, not grammatical. Only feminine animates are considered as grammatically feminine, and all other nouns are masculine' (Danielsen 2007:116)
There are only adverbial demonstrative forms which encode distance.

Cavinea has only two types of demonstratives: adverbial demonstratives and pointing demonstratives, there are no specific nominal demonstratives (cf. Guillaume 2008:80). There are 2 strategies to compencate for the lack of nominal demonstratives: (1) to mark a pointing dem, which is a peripheral element, with the relative clause marker =ke. The resulting relative clauses then can be used as noun modifiers within an NP (preceding the head noun). (2) to use a pointing dem in apposition to an NP, i.e. without any further marking (cf. Guillaume 2008:621,622).
(cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:83)

Demonstratives occur preceding the head noun. They take a classifier when preceding or replacing inanimate, countable nouns.  The animate dem-s (which distinguish gender and number) most frequently occur alone. The inanimate dem-s occur alone if referring to a concept or general item, otherwise they receive a classifier as mentioned above (cf. Miller 1999:31). In case of inanimate nouns, the plural suffix (only -ri?) occurs on both the head noun and any modifiers that accompany it (Miller 1999:52)
Demonstratives can be marked with plural only when they are used as pronouns (F.Rose p.c. 23.03.2011).
Concluded from examples (cf. Moore 1984:142, ex. 9.8) Certainty: ?
Not obligatory
Nominal demonstratives may show gender agreement
Encountered in examples, e.g. (ex.38) p.64, (ex.293) p.118.
Concluded from available examples, see p.365.

comment: No information found on demonstratives
E.g. ey thIw@ pIk [that woman PL] 'those women' (cf. Gmez 1990:75).
Obligatory; there is one demonstrative form eme used for reference to plural entities (V.Galucio, p.c.). However, demonstrative forms are more often used pronominally (and less adnominally).
Optional

It is mentioned that not all consultants like the use of demonstratives as modifiers and prefer the use of dem-s as pronominal forms. When dem-s are used as modifiers, the masculine and feminine demonstrative forms can freely substitute for each other, with the masculine form used more often (cf. Guirardello 1999:30). No example with plural dem-s as modifiers are found; it can be speculated that modifying dem.plural forms will be used with nouns denoting plural animate entities (as nominal plural marker wan is used with animate nouns only), however, no data are available.
The 'agreement' is purely semantic (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

See examples Olawsky (2006:357,369). Demonstrativesdo not exhibit any number agreement within the NP. Demonstratives can occur with a plural marker, however it occurs only in the contexts when they are nominal heads themselves (cf. Olawsky 2006:369).
Demonstratives occur with the regular plural marker if the head noun is plural (thus both can be marked with the plural number marker)
Demonstrative is a suffix which refers to items which are somewhat removed in time and space (cf. Eberhard 2009:343)
There is no clear agreement within the NP (van Gijn 2006:74)

There is no agreement in number between a demonstrative modifying a plural noun, the same forms are used as with singular nouns. When modifying a plural noun, a masc-fem distinction can be neutralized so that a masculine form of the demonstrative can be used in reference to plural female referents (cf. Facundes 2000:357)
only applies to full forms, not base forms
Pl, Animate/Pl Inanimate
By means of cls which are inherently sg or pl. Cls are obligatorily used with demonstratives (M.Crevels, p.c.)
Number marking depends on animacy. Comment from Pattie: 'Only for PNs/animates, esp. humans - inanimate Ns don't receive plural marking (animals do only optionally)'
Encountered in example (293) p.118. Demonstrative modifying a human noun occurs with a plural marker, while the noun itself is not marked for number (word order: dem-noun).

plural gfeneral o colectivo

When a demonstrative is used as an attributive modifier of a plural noun, then it does not take plural number or case marker (cf. Cole 1982:133).

Aikhenvald 2003:206).

There are demonstrative forms which can be used in reference to  masc, fem or neuter nouns. Demonstratives can occur with the suffix -n 'FEM/N' and the suffix -e 'MASC' when used with fem/n/masc nouns) (cf. Fernndez Garay 1998:235-236).
The 'agreement' in animacy is purely semantic (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

With one set of demonstratives classifiers are not used, while they are used with the other demonstrative set. In the latte case, demonstratives occur with a classifier when modifying a noun which is used with the classifer. Certainty: ?

comment: Optional. There are demonstrative forms used for inanimate referents which can take classifiers; however it occurs when shape, etc. has to be focused on (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:206)
Clauses with overtly present S and O are least frequent (8% of all sentences). Within the sentences with both S and O, the word order SV-oO (77%), OSV (19%), SOV (2%) (cf. Facundes 2000:556).

Statistics given in Frank (1990:123): Out of 283 transitive clauses, only 4 clauses have OVS word order, 3 clauses are SVO, 3 clauses - OSV, 23 clauses -SOV; 28 clauses - SV, 89 clauses - OV, and 88 clauses consist out of V.
The word order is strict (cf. Gabas 1999:94)
Word order is relatively free, SOV the most frequent one, though OSV and SVO also occur (cf. Seifart 2005:68)

In narratives, examples with VOS word order is found esp. when human or animate argument is involved. For emphasis S precedes V, this is also the means of marking of the change of S (cf. Danielsen 2007:333). If S is expressed by a pronoun, the pronoun generally precedes the predicate: S-Pred-O.
Nowadays sov but before perhaps ovs
chuinin usipichu wanakurkan ; el adorn la casa
word order is strict
However, different word order patterns correlate with tense and progressive aspect (see Vallejos 2010:466).
The patterns in the order of frequency in the data: OVS, SVO, VSO, SOV, and (least common) VOS (M&M 1999:142)
'The basic constituent order in Desano is OV with the subject (S) generally preceding the verb (V) and the object/patient (O)' (Miller 1999:2) Certainty: ?
Underlying, topicalization gives SOV

Dixon (2004:86) mentions that '[m]ore than half the clauses in Jarawara texts are intransitive', and only about 3% of transitive clauses have both A and O stated. In such cases, in about 85% of the time the A precedes the O and about 73% of the time the O precedes the A. The order is not fixes and grammatically not significant (cf. Dixon 2004:86).
Topicalized subjects can occur before and after OV (story)

P.Epps (2008:751) notes that '[v]erb-final constituent order is basic and most frequent in Hup' and that the relative order of A and O is highly flexible and is determined primarily by pragmatic factors- 'the relative newness or givenness of information' (Epps 2008:750).

VOS order is also very common, and based on the natural speech samples. In general, in natural speech, sentences with two nominal phrases is infrequent (cf. Grondona 1998:14)
NB: The order SVO is mentioned as most neutral in Gibson (1996:26).
Hovdhaugen  Inverse,  Torero  Direct
Mentioned that VOS is a 'normal pattern'
predominant VO

'There is a strong tendency to have either a subject or object present, but not both'.Out of 714 sentences having transitive verbs, only 99 have both S and O (about 12%). 'Of these 99 cases, only 48 have SOV order.The total number of sentences in the corpus that are not consistent with SOV order is 160 (about 12%)'. Weber (1996:16) gives the following statistics: Out of 1309 sentences: intransitive sentences: 53% of the sentences with subject present (76% word order SV, 24% word order VS). Transitive sentences: 31% of the sentences with subject present (75% word order SV, 68% word order OV); 69% of the sentences with subject absent (71% word order OV). 'There is a strong tendency to have either a subject or object present, but not both.' (cf. Weber (1996:16) for more details).
atoq-qa wasi-n-caw fyesta-ta rura-na-n ka-rqa 'el zorro iba a dar una fiesta en su casa.'

Proximal demonstrative is often used to express referentiality and definiteness. However, this use might be a result of the influence from Spanish, since dem. are also often used even in front of proper names, which is pervasive in Spanish (see Vallejos 2010:220).
Morse & Maxwell (1999:96) lists several demonstrative prefixes which can encode definiteness/indefiniteness along with some deictic meaning.

The referential proclitic i precedes the head of the NP to indicate that the referent noun has already been mentioned or understood by the context (cf. Mortensen 1999:37). Also: when this referential proclitic precedes a verb, the action concerned is reciprocal. There is the dem.form m- 'this, the' which occurs preceding a noun which has been mentioned in a given context if it is of any importance in the story.'Most participants and props are preceded by m- only once in a discourse' (Mortensen 1999:135). The demonstrative h- 'that' is anaphoric in reference and encodes thematic distance (cf. Mortensen 1999:136).
Certainty: ?

There are forms afa/efe and ifa/ife (appear to be used interchangeably) which are employed to 'specify a core argument without referring to it directly, often relating anaphorically to a coreferential NP in an earlier clause which did refer to it directly' (Dixon 2004:369). Over 80% of the occurences of the forms are as copula subject; they almost always make a full NP. Certainty: ?

'Specifier articles are homonymous with free third person pronouns, with one difference: unlike third person pronouns, articles do not have double plural marking for feminine forms and can combine with classifiers'. The articles occur preceding the noun, and they can be used anaphorically as heads of the noun phrases. Articles are never used when the noun is modified by a demonstrative, the gestural deictic khi, the distributive individualiser napada, the general indefinite pa:-, with numerals, or with quantifiers. (Aikhenvald 2003:204).

There is only one demonstrative form which attaches to the end of the nominal string. No corresponding demonstrative form with a proximate meaning has been found (Eberhard 2009:343-4).

Adverbial demonstratives only can encode visibility; there is no separate form for 'invisible', but it seems to be used mostly to refer to invisible objects. (Pronominal and adnominal demonstratives encode exclusively gender) (cf. Sakel 2003:123)

Cavinea has only two types of demonstratives: adverbial demonstratives and pointing demonstratives, there are no specific nominal demonstratives.  Both types of dem-s encode 3 distance degrees  (cf. Guillaume 2008:80). There are 2 strategies to compencate for the lack of nominal demonstratives: (1) to mark a pointing dem, which is a peripheral element, with the relative clause marker =ke. The resulting relative clauses then can be used as noun modifiers within an NP (preceding the head noun). (2) to use a pointing dem in apposition to an NP, i.e. without any further marking (cf. Guillaume 2008:621,622).

comment: The set of 'positional' dem-s is used when the referent is seen or perceived (heard, felt, smelled) by S, if not, then 'absential' dem-s are used (Set 3). However, the distal form of 'elevated' dem (Set 2) is used when the referent is NOT seen by only perceived (heard, smelled, felt) by S. Set 3 is used when the referent is not seen or perceived by the speaker.

Demonstrative forms can occur with the number marker -ge (e.g.: a-wi [near-RELATIVE] 'this', a-wi-ge [near-RELATIVE-PL] 'these' (cf. Crowell 1979:225). Nonato 2008:53) gives the following: when plural noun is modified by a demonstrative, the plural marker occurs on the noun only. Demonstrative can receive the plural marking also if the head noun is omitted, e.g.: aw kare [aw karo e = this fish PL] 'these fishes', awge [aw ge = this PL] 'these ones'.
Plural enclitic can occur on a demonstrative only if the demonstrative is used pronominally (not adnominally) (see Vallejos 2010:217).

Adverbial demonstratives can be forms which are composed of dem-roots (used pronominally and adnominally) occuring with a locative suffix, or other roots than those used as pron.and adnom. (cf. Mortensen 1999:35)
Basically, dem-s are used pronominally or adverbially (they have different forms in those cases)

NB: Dem.roots used pronominally and adnominally receive a nominalizing suffix, whereas the same dem.root used adverbially does not occur with any marker.

NB: Pronominal demonstratives seem to be used in adverbial function. The morphological composition of pronominal demonstratives is:  tox 'subordinator' + the demonstrative clitics (which are used as adnominal demonstratives) (cf. Terraza 2009:103).
Adverbial demonstratives are formed by the use of oblique marker n- on neuter demonstratives (cf. Haude 2006:145).

comment: Adverbial demonstrative are composed of demonstrative base + locative suffix (cf. Olawsky 2006:176). Adverbial demonstratives can express a large variety of meanings: in sight vs. out of sight, directional, locational, punctual vs. non-punctual (cf. Olawsky 2006:224).
Demonstratives receive the locative case markers forming demonstrative adverbs of location (cf. Romero-Figeroa 1997:72)
Same root but used with classifying morphemes (derivational suffixes, not inflectional as in the question).

Adverbial demonstratives (nono 'here' and ono 'there') are formed by the root ne- 'prox' and o- 'dist' plus locative ano. Adnominal demonstratives are deictic roots plus 3rd p.sg form -a, thus forming adnominal demonstratives na 'this', oa 'that') (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:49, 71).
see example (501) p. 270 for a demonstrative occurring with a locative case marker to express adverbial meaning.

jati 'there', niya 'here'

There is however not a very clear distinction of distances ('close but not 'here'', 'very close, usually 'here'', 'rather far away, usually not visible') (cf. Sakel 2003:123). Certainty: ?

Terraza 2009:103).

Adverbial demonstratives are formed by demonstrative root ta preceded by 1st or 2nd personal pronominal prefix denoting proximity or distance (respectively) and followed by the locative morpheme ri 'LOC' (cf. Alves 2004:78).
The adverbial demonstrative forms are: neno 'here',  jain 'there', ono 'further away over there' (Valenzuela 2003:169).
There are 4 adverbial demonstrative forms.
Certainty: ?
Demonstrative adverbs distinguish an intermediate distance degree between proximal and distal (cf. Guirardello 1999:32)

Three forms of adverbial demonstratives (?) are mentioned in the grammar: one for proximal use and two for distal use; the distal forms have a visibility distinction (seen vs. unseen) (cf. Eberhard 2009:349). Certainty: ?
Adverbial demonstratives are: nono 'here' and ono 'there' (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:49)

Dependent is marked with a gen.case marker which is derived from accusative. Personal pronouns used as possessors are marked with accusative case marker (see Overall 2007:199, 261). Construction is as follows: POSR-acc/gen POSSD-pers.pos.suf. There is also a possibility to mark possession by the following construction: POSR-pos POSSD (see Overall 2007:210).

In Ika, the genitive case marker (or possession marker?) has two forms zei and z-. Zei is realized as an independent form and belongs to the (pro)/noun denoting the possessor, z- is phonologically bound to the following head as a proclitic, while belonging to the possessor (cf. Frank 1990:41).
Construction is: [POSR possessive.pronoun POSSD].  Possessive pronouns for 1sg and 3psg/du/pl have the same form, namely: i (cf. Smeets 2008:103).

With alienably possessed nouns: possessive marker at occurring between the possessor and possesed. Word worder: POSSR pos.marker POSSD. With inalienably possessed nouns, the nouns are juxtaposed with no marking for possession, word order POSSR-POSSD (cf. Gabas 1999:141)

NB: Possessive constructions are marked by a low tone on last syllable of the possessor or first syllable of the possessed according to the number of syllables of both elements. So there is a tonal pattern that affects both possessor and possessed (Frank Seifart, p.c.) Certainty: ?

No examples found, highly probably the answer is 'a' (in constructions with inalienably possessed nouns, overt nominal possessor does not receive any marking, while possessed occurs with a personal possessive prefix: POSSR  pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Crowell 1979:215). (See also comment for Q8.3, 8.4).

In Mosetn, there are two ways of expressing possession: (i) involving a linker morpheme (-tyi' 'masc' and -si' 'fem') suffixed on the possessor which agrees in gender with the possessed, and (ii) involving personal pronouns suffixed on the possessed which agrees in person, number and gender with the possessor (cf. Sakel 2003:52).
Possessive marker =ja is used both with nominal and pronminal possessor (cf.Guillaume 2008:407).
Pedruchu-j atasi-n / Pedruchu-paj atasi-n ; mujer de Pedro
Possessive marker is realized as a bound morpheme

There is alienable-inalienable distinction in the sense that kinship terms are always possessed. However, the use of different constructions depends on the animacy of the possessor. Only animate possessor is marked by the suffix -I 'genitive', possession with inanimate possessor is usually represented by use of a classifier or by a compound noun construction, with no special case marking (Morse & Maxwell 1999:118,91)

Only in cases of alienable possession (inalienable possession is formed by unmarked juxtaposed possessor and possessed). Miller (1999) referrers to ya as a genitive case marker, I treat it here as the possessive marker, since Desano does not seem to have a developed case marking system. It does have specific object marker, locative marker, and instrumental marker. Besides, that 'genitive' marker is a free form in Desano, which might be more characteristic of the possessive marker.

NB: Possession is not encoded morphologically, but is signalled by possessor-possessed word order.  With certain nouns the relational morpheme l- is used with personal possessive prefix for 1st or 2nd person of Series II, though some nouns do not require the use of the relational morpheme (cf. Rose 2003:228-229)

In the examples given neither possessor nor possessed is marked: POSSR POSSD. However, it is not clear whether these are instances of inalienable possession (see ex. 142-144, Mortensen 1999:38). Certainty: ?

Possessor is marked with alienably possessed nouns only (possessive marker is realized as a free (not bound) possessive morpheme, see also Hup); nominal possessor is simply juxtaposed to inalienably possessed nouns  (Dixon 2004:295)
The possessive marker is realized as a free (not bound) morpheme (cf. Epps 2008:225)
Nouns denoting the possessor is marked by 'nuclear case marker -a' (cf. Seki 2000:117).

With alienably possessed nouns: nominal possessor occurs with a genitive suffix. Possessor can either follow or precede the possessed. With inalienably possessed nouns: nominal possessor can be unmarked, and the word order is mainly possessor-possessed (cf. Martins 2004:547).
A possessiv element occurs between the possessed and possessor (either nominal or pronominal). It is not clear whether the possessive element belongs syntactically with the possessor. Certainty: ?

comment: Possessive expressions have a construction of a compound. The 3rd person possessive prefix on the possessed is obligatory, possessor precedes the possessed, e.g. POSSR-3rd.p-POSSED (cf. Telles 2002:159)

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only. There are 2 classifiers in Wich:  lo is one is used only with referents denoting all kinds of animals (insects, reptiles, etc. incl.), whereas qa is used with all referents, whether they are inanimates, animates or human. There are two possible constructions with alienable nouns: (a) POSR cls POSSD, and (b) POSR pers.pos.pref-cls POSSD. Constructions with inalienable nouns do not require the use of a classifier. There are two possible constructions with inalienable nouns: (a) POSR POSSD, and (b) POSR pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Terraza 2009:61,64,98). (Comment OK: the answers for Q 8.1. and 8.2. can be controversial, as it is hard to determine whether the head or the dependent is marked in this case. Answered as head-marked, since classifier (which can be regarded as the head) receives personal possessive prefixes, while possessor remains unmarked and can be omitted).

In constructions with alienably possessed nouns, the most common construction in use is: [POSSD pers.pos.clitics POSSR], where 'pers.pos.clitics' are so-called Nominal Inflectional Clitics which inflect for person, number and gender of the possessor. Noun denoting the possessor can be omitted, in which case the possessive construction with alienable nouns looks as follows: [POSSD pers.pos.clitic], e.g. nanacam' nucun [fish:species poss:3sg.masc] 'his fish'. (See possessive constructions in Moseten, where possessive marker agreeing with the possessed occurs on the possessor and not on the possessed.) In constructions with inalienably possessed noun, the most common strategy to mark possession is to use possessive suffixes which encode person, number and gender of the possessor, e.g. xiri-con xijam [house-3sg.masc m:name] 'Xijam's house', or xiri-con [house-3sg.masc ] 'his house' (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:150,235).
Juxtaposition of unmarked possessor and possessed: nasa kiwe [pez land] 'the land of pez' (cf. Jung 2008:121).
Construction with alienable nouns looks like: [POSSR]  clf-possed  [POSSD] (Tom and Doris Payne, p.c.)
Not marked with alienably possessed nouns; with inalienably possessed nouns POSSD receives a personal possessive prefix  (word order [POSSD POSSR]).

Possessive constructions with alienably possessed nouns involve the use of morpheme -pin 'ownership of' occurring on the noun denoting the possessor or occurring with a personal possessive prefix: POSSD POSSR-pos.marker. Possessive construction with inalienably possessed nouns: POSSR-POSSD, or pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Girn 2008:178)
Both nominal possessor and possessed are usually marked. If overt nominal possessor is absent, then the noun denoting the possessed entity receives a person possessive suffix (cf. Weber 1989:254)

comment: Possession may be expressed by compounds; there is no morphological marking in possessive constructions, e.g. gabliel.maliwunon [gabriel bucket] 'Gabriel's bucket' (cf. Araujo 2004:101).

With alienably possessed nouns the possessive constructions look as follows: [POSSR {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [POSSR POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}], where clitic 'e' may optionally precede or follow the possessed with no change in meaning. In cases of pronominal possessor the construction with alienably nouns is as follows: [pos.pronoun POSSD] (for 1st and 2nd person possessor) and [3rd personal pronoun {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [3rd personal pronoun POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}] (for 3rd person possessor). In possessive constructions with kinship terms (inalienably possessed nouns), the construction is similar except that the poss.clitic 'e' always follows the kinship term and is preceded by an additional suffix which is phonologically determined. Possession of a body part is indicated either a personal or a possessive pronoun preceding the body part (cf. (Gmez 1990:52-56).
Noun denoting possessor receives the genetive case marker -n.

There is no marking on either possessor or possessed with alienable nouns (which is the majority), inalienable nouns are marked (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:483). Besides there is an alternative construction with a cross-referencing prefix + -ya- + possessed clf followed by the possessed noun; this construction is used both with alien. and inalien. nouns (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:134)
Word order: possessed-possessor
Order is more frequent POSSD POSR

Possessive morpheme -k(a)te. Guirardello (1999:77) mentions that this marker 'can also be used for indicating 'kind of thing' rather than the possession of a thing': karaiw-kate kuman [non.Indian-POSS bean] ' non-Indian bean (lit: beans of non-Indian people)'. In constructions with inalienably possessed nouns, the possessor is juxtaposed to the possessed with no marking (word order: posser-possed) (cf. Guirardello 1999:17,76)

NB: There are several possessive constructions possible in NP in Urarina. Simple juxtaposition is the default case where two nouns (of any type) are involved. Such construction is also common when possessor is not expressed by a overt noun and when possessor refers to 1st or 2nd person. In that case an unmarked personal pronoun is used to express the possessor. In cases when possessor is not overtly expressed and refers to the 3rd person, the most common construction is with the use of possessive marker raj + POSSD (the possessive marker raj can occur in 2 different contexts: (a) as an optional marker between possessor and possessum, and (b) as a substitute for the 3rd person pronoun in possessor function) (cf. Olawsky 2006:333,340). Among possible strategies to mark possession, the construction [proclitic-POSSD] can be used instead of free personal pronouns. Nouns which are only marked with proclitics are typical of the traditional language, they  usually occur with formerly inalienab

Besides the possessive construction where possessum receives a personal possessive marker indicating the possessor, Warao has an alternative construction: '(i) by means of the genitive postposition a 'of' following the possessor within a possr-possed NP, and (ii) by means of the genitive postposition abitu 'of' following any noun.'  (Romero-Figeroa 1997:91). In cases when possessor is expressed by a personal pronoun, the postpositions occur with the personal pronoun.

In Kwaza, the derivational possessive marker -dy- which is suffixed to the nominal posssessor, is followed in turn by the nominalizer -hy (which serves as a semantically neutral classifier) (cf. van der Voort 2004:181)

Overall (2007:199): In Aguaruna possession is normally head-marked (on the possessum) and dependent-marked (on the possessor), but there is also a nominal possessive marker that marks possessors without requiring any marking on the possessum. Nouns fall into two classes based on the marking they take as possessum. The first group, which I label suffixing, marks possession entirely with suffixes in all persons, while the second group (labelled vowel-changing) uses a combination of suffixes and root apophony in second person, and root apophony only in first plural and third persons. The classes are not distinguished when the possessor is first person singular; then all nouns are marked only with a suffix -hu. The marking forms two layers, one marking the noun as possessed and the second indexing the person of the possessor.

In Ika, the genitive case marker (or possession marker?) has two forms zei and z-. Zei is realized as an independent form and belongs to the (pro)/noun denoting the possessor, z- is phonologically bound to the following head as a proclitic, while belonging to the possessor (cf. Frank 1990:41).
Construction is: [POSR possessive.pronoun POSSD].  Possessive pronouns for 1sg and 3psg/du/pl have the same form, namely: i (cf. Smeets 2008:103).
