NB: Possessive pronouns are less frequently used for possessor marking, as this is done by possessor proclitics on nouns. However, there are some otherwise not possessable and non-derivable nouns that can get possessor marking by means of possessive pronouns. In this case they are modifiers within NPs. This mainly holds for Spanish loanwords. (Danielsen 2007:108).

In Mosetn, there are two ways of expressing possession: (i) involving a linker morpheme (-tyi' 'masc' and -si' 'fem') suffixed on the possessor which agrees in gender with the possessed, and (ii) involving personal pronouns suffixed on the possessed which agrees in person, number and gender with the possessor (cf. Sakel 2003:52).
Possessive marker =ja is used with both nominal and pronominal possessor (cf.Guillaume 2008:407).
nisi-p lloken-i ; mi toro

Short forms of pronouns 'function as possessive pronouns, whereas long forms do not. Pronominal forms in possessive function can appear unbounded or cliticized to the possessed noun' (Vallejos 2010:208).

The forms of possessive pronouns show that 3rd p sg pronouns are combined with the genitive marker -I. The stems of all other possessive pronouns (1st and 2nd sg+pl and 3rd pl pronouns) 'are clearly related to the corresponding personal pronouns, but there are differences', particular in the form of 1st and 2nd sg. (Morse & Maxwell 1999:81-82,125).
In cases of alienable possession (cf. Miller 1999:48). The possession marker realized as a free morpheme: ya.

The same forms as personal pronouns are used as possessors (see Mortensen 1999:20). Licht (1999:23) notes, however, that these do not receive the primary stress and thus differ from the same forms used as arguments of verbs. 'The coreferent forms of the 1st and 2nd person pronouns are most often used in NE as possessive adjectives when the referent is the subject of the sentence' (Mortensen 1999:43). Additionally: pos.pronouns for 1sg and 2sg can receive -re on the stem, other pronouns receive the locative postposition -de 'in, on, at, while, within the limits of'  (which occasionally can also appear on 1sg and 2sg) to denote possession. The locative postposition -de can also be attached to noun (phrase) to denote possession (no examples available) (cf. Mortensen 1999:45)
C is used to focus on the possessor
Paypa mama but even: nuca mama

In cases when the alienable possessor is a singular pronoun, the form looks as follows: 1sg o- plus kaa => oko 'my', 2sg ti- plus kaa => tika 'your (sg)', 3sg hina plus kaa => hinaka 'his/her' (Dixon 2004:296). In cases when the inalienable possessor in a singular pronoun, it gets prefixed to the possessed - with some nouns, while with other nouns the possessor is expressed by a free pronoun; plural pronouns are always free words (cf. Dixon 2004:77,325).

With alienably possessed nouns: marked possessor: possessive pronouns are used which are composed of personal pronouns followed by a genetive suffix (except for the 1sg that has a different form. 2sg has two forms: pers.pronoun+gen.suf, and a fused form of pers.pronoun and the genetive suffix, cf. Martins 2004:361). Possessor can either follow or precede the possessed in these constructions.  With inalienably possessed nouns: unmarked possessor: personal pronouns are used. The word order is mainly possessor-possessed (cf. Martins 2004:547).

There are only 3 pos.pronouns in Awa Pit: for 1,2, and 3 p.singular; there are no plural forms. In order to express the meaning of 1,2,3 plural pronoun, e.g. 'our house' two constructions can be used: (1) to use 1sg pos.pronoun: 'my house', in this case the translation is ambiguous between 'mine' and 'ours', (2) to use 1pl subject personal pronoun immediately followed by the noun possessed; in this case no other constituent may appear between pronoun and the noun (cf. Curnow 1997:124).
A possessiv element occurs between the possessed and possessor (either nominal or pronominal). It is not clear whether the possessive element belongs syntactically with the possessor. Certainty: ?
contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: With alienably possessed nouns; with inalienably possessed nouns person markers are prefixed directly to the possessed noun.
Example 412, there is no independent marking of the possessor

Fleck (2003:252) notes that although possessive pronouns can be considered personal pronouns in the genetive case (they all end in -n), the pos.pronoun forms cannot be readily segmented as they are no correlates in the language for some of the forms without -n.

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only. There are 2 classifiers in Wich:  lo is one is used only with referents denoting all kinds of animals (insects, reptiles, etc. incl.), whereas qa is used with all referents, whether they are inanimates, animates or human. There are two possible constructions with alienable nouns: (a) POSR cls POSSD, and (b) POSR pers.pos.pref-cls POSSD. Constructions with inalienable nouns do not require the use of a classifier. There are two possible constructions with inalienable nouns: (a) POSR POSSD, and (b) POSR pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Terraza 2009:61,64,98). (Comment OK: the answers for Q 8.1. and 8.2. can be controversial, as it is hard to determine whether the head or the dependent is marked in this case. Answered as head-marked, since classifier (which can be regarded as the head) receives personal possessive prefixes, while possessor remains unmarked and can be omitted).

In Movima, for all persons except 1st person singular, the possessive personal pronouns are clitized to the possessed. When the possessor is 1st person singular, possession is encoded by the referential element  attached to the determiner (cf. Haude 2006:228).

In constructions with alienably possessed nouns, the most common construction in use is: [POSSD pers.pos.clitics POSSR], where 'pers.pos.clitics' are so-called Nominal Inflectional Clitics which inflect for person, number and gender of the possessor. Noun denoting the possessor can be omitted, in which case the possessive construction with alienable nouns looks as follows: [POSSD pers.pos.clitic], e.g. nanacam' nucun [fish:species poss:3sg.masc] 'his fish'. (See possessive constructions in Moseten, where possessive marker agreeing with the possessed occurs on the possessor and not on the possessed.) In constructions with inalienably possessed noun, the most common strategy to mark possession is to use possessive suffixes which encode person, number and gender of the possessor, e.g. xiri-con xijam [house-3sg.masc m:name] 'Xijam's house', or xiri-con [house-3sg.masc ] 'his house' (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:150,235).

NB: In constructions with pronominal possessor, possessive pronoun forms coincide largely with unmarked personal pronouns. There is just one exception for 3rd sg: tjaxj 'poss.3sg' instead of tj: '3sg'.  Noun denoting the possessed entity is left unmarked (cf. Jung 2008:121,136).
Constructions with alienable nouns and pronominal possessor look like:  (a) pers.pos.pref-clf- possed  [POSSD],  or (b) Personal.pro  clf-possed  [POSSD]  (Tom and Doris Payne, p.c.).

[OK comment: the answer 'personal.pronoun-pos.marker' is not exact in this case. Instead of personal pronoun - a personal prefix is used (which is morphologically a reduce form and is not a free form]. Possessive constructions with alienably possessed nouns involve the use of morpheme -pin 'ownership of' occurring on the noun denoting the possessor or occurring with a personal possessive prefix: POSSD POSSR-pos.marker. Possessive construction with inalienably possessed nouns: POSSR-POSSD, or pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Girn 2008:178)
Both nominal possessor and possessed are usually marked. If overt nominal possessor is absent, then the noun denoting the possessed entity receives a person possessive suffix (cf. Weber 1989:254)
normally the pronoun is not relaized
Normally the pronoun is not realized

The same possessive marker -paj is used for both nouns and pronouns denoting possessor. In the 1p sg/pl, the possessive marker is usually omitted on possessive adjectives, but is obligatorily retained on possessive pronouns (e.g. 'that house is mine/ours') (cf. Cole 1982:115).
normally the pronoun is not realized
normally the pronoun is not realized

NB: <The Q is answered as [POSSR pos.marker POSSD], however, the possessive marker has to occur with the 'relational prefix' resulting in [POSSR REL-pos.marker POSSD] or [pers.pos.pref-REL-pos.marker POSSD]. The presence of the relational prefix is phonologically conditioned occurs if the noun begins with the vowel, which is the case of the possessive marker (which is a generic noun meaning 'thing, belongings, possession' (cf. Rodrigues 1999:190).> Possessive constructions with alienable nouns: either nominal or pronominal possessor is followed by a possessive marker (the possessive/genitive marker occurs with a relational prefix). In possessive constructions with inalienable nouns the possessive/genitive marker is not used; personal possessive prefix occurs on an inalienably possessed noun either directly (if the noun begins with a consonant) or with a relational prefix (if the noun begins with a vowel) (cf. Alves 2004:48). Certainty: ?

comment: With alienably possessed nouns the possessive constructions look as follows: [POSSR {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [POSSR POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}], where clitic 'e' may optionally precede or follow the possessed with no change in meaning. In cases of pronominal possessor the construction with alienably nouns is as follows: [pos.pronoun POSSD] (for 1st and 2nd person possessor) and [3rd personal pronoun {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [3rd personal pronoun POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}] (for 3rd person possessor). In possessive constructions with kinship terms (inalienably possessed nouns), the construction is similar except that the poss.clitic 'e' always follows the kinship term and is preceded by an additional suffix which is phonologically determined. Possession of a body part is indicated either a personal or a possessive pronoun preceding the body part (cf. (Gmez 1990:52-56).
Personal pronouns receive genetive case marker -n and as such function as pronominal possessive modifiers (cf. Valenzuela 2003:184).

There is no marking on either possessor or possessed with alienable nouns (which is the majority), inalienable nouns are marked (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:483). Besides there is an alternative construction with a cross-referencing prefix + -ya- + possessed clf followed by the possessed noun; this construction is used both with alien. and inalien. nouns (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:134)

In constructions with inalienably possessed nouns: there are the following possibilities of possession marking. (i) with body parts and intimate objects (clothing, adornments, hammocks, shadows, homes, villages, names, pets, etc.), in case the possessor is either 1st or 2nd person sg or pl, the personal pronoun occurs before the possessed noun without any extra morphology. In case the possessor refers to a 3rd person sg or pl, there is an additional alternative construction in use: the noun denoting the possessed receives the possive suffix -ake. (ii) With kinship terms the situation is similar but slightly more complicated: if possessor refers to 1, 2, or 3rd person sg or pl possessor expressed by a personal pronoun can occur with no extra marking before the possessed. There is similarly an additional alternative construction when the possessor is a 3p. Namely: with 3p.sg the prefix tsi-/t- is used; with 3p.pl the suffix -ake is used (the same suffix as with body parts) (cf. Guirardel

NB: There are several possessive constructions possible in NP in Urarina. Simple juxtaposition is the default case where two nouns (of any type) are involved. Such construction is also common when possessor is not expressed by a overt noun and when possessor refers to 1st or 2nd person. In that case an unmarked personal pronoun is used to express the possessor. In cases when possessor is not overtly expressed and refers to the 3rd person, the most common construction is with the use of possessive marker raj + POSSD (the possessive marker raj can occur in 2 different contexts: (a) as an optional marker between possessor and possessum, and (b) as a substitute for the 3rd person pronoun in possessor function) (cf. Olawsky 2006:333,340). Among possible strategies to mark possession, the construction [proclitic-POSSD] can be used instead of free personal pronouns. Nouns which are only marked with proclitics are typical of the traditional language, they  usually occur with formerly inalienab
1sg and 3sg yes, for  other persons bare pronouns function as possessives

Besides the possessive construction where possessum receives a personal possessive marker indicating the possessor, Warao has an alternative construction: '(i) by means of the genitive postposition a 'of' following the possessor within a possr-possed NP, and (ii) by means of the genitive postposition abitu 'of' following any noun.'  (Romero-Figeroa 1997:91). In cases when possessor is expressed by a personal pronoun, the postpositions occur with the personal pronoun.

Similarly to the possessive constructions with nominal possessor, the derivational possessive marker -dy- is suffixed to the pronominal posssessor and is followed in turn by the nominalizer -hy (which serves as a semantically neutral classifier) (cf. van der Voort 2004:181). Exclusively with 3P the possessum can receive the marker -tjate, which is the preferred construction with 3p possessor (cf. van der Voort 2004:200)

Sg possessive pronouns are formed by personal pronoun + possessive suffix -fen (in a reduced form -fe for 1 and 3 p.sg, and -i for 2p.sg.); plural possessive pronouns are formed by personal pronouns and suffix -kõ/tõ (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:72).

Besides the person poss.prefixes on the possessed noun, the possessor can be expressed additionally by a personal pronoun (cf. van Gijn 2006:74). Yurakar has a number of nouns which cannot take the possessive prefix directly, and require a classifier in order to be possessed. These are nouns denoting domestic animals used in possessive constructions referring to ownership (cf. van Gijn 2006:74,117)

Possessor is optional, if present them the personal pronoun indiatign the possessor occurs with the accusative marker. If absent, person and number of the possessor is indicated by the sufixes on the possessed noun (see Overall 2007:261).
Certainty: ?
There seem to be two constructions possible with alienably possessed nouns: personal.pronoun  [POSSD]-pos.marker, and pers.pos.pref-[POSSD]-possessed (Facundes 2000:219, 201-202).

In Ika, the genitive case marker (or possession marker?) has two forms zei and z-. Zei is realized as an independent form and belongs to the (pro)/noun denoting the possessor, z- is phonologically bound to the following head as a proclitic, while belonging to the possessor (cf. Frank 1990:41).

With alienably possessed nouns: Possessive.pronoun-POSSD (with inalienably possessed nouns the possessed noun occurs with a possessive pronominal clitic, or a noun with no possessive marker (Gabas 1999:116).
A possessive prefix on the head noun may be used

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only. There are 4 classifiers in Bororo (-ke 'food', -aku 'domesticated animal', -imo 'adornment', -o 'general'). Possessive construction with alienable nouns: pers.pos.pref-cls POSSD. Construction with inalienable nouns (does not require the use of a classifier): pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Crowell 1979:215, Nonato 2008:59). No examples found for possessive constructions with nominal possessor and alienably possessed noun (e.g. my friend's stone). Juxtaposition of unmarked personal pronoun denoting possessor and unmarked noun denoting the possessed entity (cf. Jung 2008:121).

Along with this construction, there is a construction with the use of the suffix no 'poss', which is homophonous with the nominalizer no 'nmz1'. In this derivational process some nouns show a vowel change in the first syllable of the noun base: nihapin [ni=hapi-no : 1SG=jar-POSS] 'my jar' (Danielsen 2007:123)

Sakel 2003:52).

NB: There are two basic classes of nouns (suffixing and vowel-changing) which roughly corresponds to alienably-inalienably nouns; however, there are quite many exceptions and, more than that, 'possession is never obligatory or inherent: nouns of both classes can appear outside of a possessive construction' (Overall 2007:207). There are about three nouns which are inherently possessed (page?).

Kinship terms are obligatorily possessed. A few kinships take possessive prefix 'xi- 'his, her' in 3rd sg. (NOTE: this one is procliticized to the kinship nouns, normally they are free morphemes) (Cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:126)

Kinship terms, for instance, muj 'mother', papa 'pather', keke 'grandmother' etc., have to occur with the overt statement of the possessor (either a noun or possessive pronoun). They may occur without being determined by a possessive pronoun only in the syntactic function of a vocative (Larcio Bcelar, p.c. 22.03.2011). Further, there are nouns which occur with the neutral prefix i- (mainly denoting body parts, but interestingly not with parts of the body that can be trimmed or cut (hair, nails) or plucked (teeth) L.Bacelar, p.c.). These could have been regarded as inalienable nouns, or as nouns with the empty formative root i-. Similar phenomenon in Saban and some other languages of the region (cf. H. van der Voort 2009:366 (Possession, ed. B.McGregor), and H. van der Voort, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:103 (A grammar of Saban )).

comment: Araujo (2004:102) notes that '[a]lienability is not morphologically distinct in Saban', while this distinction is widespread in Nambikwaran languages. Inanlienable nouns are frequently marked by the prefix a- in those languages. In Saban, all nouns referring to human body parts and animal parts begin with the vowel i or a; on this fact there are several suggestions: possible vestiges of an inalienability morphemes in Proto-Nambikwara (J.Costa, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:102);  an areal feature (H. van der Voort, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:103) (cf. Araujo 2004:102).
It is more difficult in Tiriyo to form a noun (of a category of body part, kinship term, etc), which is unpossessed than, for instance, in English (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

Olawsky (2006:350,354) notes that Urarina might had inalienably possessed nouns at an earlier stage, but the feature has been largely lost over time. There are some some traces of inalienability: nouns denoting body parts, kinship terms, some human attributes and a few abstract nouns can occur with a possessive proclitic marking possession instead of free personal pronoun (the use of proclitics or free pronouns are both acceptable).
Certainty: ?

Headless poss.constructions with a cls and referring to animal body parts, the poss.morpheme -dy- is often (not always) optional. 'No evidence that -dy- is optional in similar constructions which involve body parts of humans' (van der Voort 2004:185). If body part classifiers are analysed as bound noun roots, they can be regarded as obligatorily possessed by the dummy element e- (H. van der Voort, p.c.).
Kinship terms

NB: There are two basic classes of nouns (suffixing and vowel-changing) which roughly corresponds to alienably-inalienably nouns; however, there are quite many exceptions and, more than that, 'possession is never obligatory or inherent: nouns of both classes can appear outside of a possessive construction' (Overall 2007:207). There are about three nouns which are inherently possessed (page?).
Concluded from material available

In possessive constructions with inalienably possessed nouns, no morphological marker denoting possession is used (kema kuwu [tapir head] 'tapir's head'). The noun denoting the possessor always precedes the possessed (cf. Facundes 2000:152). The following constructions is used with inalienably possessed nouns (with no overt nominal possessor) pers.pos.pref-[POSSD] (cf. Facundes 2000:158).

NB: yes and no. It is stated in the grammar and illustrated by examples that identical constructions are used for kinship terms, part-whole relations and ownership relation (cf. Frank 1990:41-42). However, it is also mentioned elsewhere in the grammar that kinship terms carry person prefixes indicating whose kinsperson is being referred to, e.g. n-kaki [1SG-father] 'my father' (cf. Frank 1990:19).

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only. There are 4 classifiers in Bororo (-ke 'food', -aku 'domesticated animal', -imo 'adornment', -o 'general'). Possessive construction with alienable nouns: pers.pos.pref-cls POSSD. Construction with inalienable nouns (does not require the use of a classifier): pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Crowell 1979:215, Nonato 2008:59). No examples found for possessive constructions with nominal possessor and alienably possessed noun (e.g. my friend's stone). (Comment OK: the answers for Q 8.1. and 8.2. can be controversial, as it is hard to determine whether the head or the dependent is marked in this case. Answered as head-marked, since classifier (which can be regarded as the head) receives personal possessive prefixes, while possessor remains unmarked and can be omitted (cf. Nonato 2008:61); further, the possessed noun and not the possessor receives possessive prefix with inalienably possessed nouns) (see Wich for simil

NB: As mentioned, alienably possessed nouns can be marked (i) either only by pers.pos.prefixes on the possessed, or (ii) by pers.pos.prefixes and additionally  the suffix no 'poss' on the possessed (the suffix is homophonous with the nominalizer no 'nmz1'). With inalienably nouns, only the first option is possible (i.e. and not with the use of the suffix -no 'pos').

Sakel (2003:72) notes that nouns denoting possessum normally receive a person clitic agreeing in gender with the possessor. However, there are examples where agreement is done with the possessed instead of the possessor; this seems to occur primarily among younger speakers, and it primarily occurs with inalienable possessed nouns such as kinship terms.  See also Sakel (2003:96)

Possessive constructions with alienably possessed nouns involve the use of morpheme -pin 'ownership of' occuring on the noun denoting the possessor or occuring with a personal possessive prefix: POSSD POSSR-pos.marker. Possessive construction with inalienably possessed nouns: POSSR-POSSD, or pers.pos.pref-POSSD (cf. Girn 2008:178)

There is alienable-inalienable distinction in the sense that kinship terms are always possessed. However, the use of different constructions depends on the animacy of the possessor. Only animate possessor is marked by the suffix -I 'genitive', possession with inanimate possessor is usually represented by use of a classifier or by a compound noun construction, with no special case marking (Morse & Maxwell 1999:118,91). A few kinships take possessive prefix 'xi- 'his, her' in 3rd sg. (NOTE: this one is procliticized to the kinship nouns, normally they are free morphemes) (Cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:126)
Alienable: possr+poss.marker+possed. Inalienable: possr +possed.
Nothing said about it
In constructions with inalienably possessed nouns there is no REL morpheme: the noun denoting possessum occurs with a personal possessive prefix only (M.Crevels, p.c.)
Possessor is marked with alienably possessed nouns only; nominal possessor is simply juxtaposed to inalienably possessed nouns  (Dixon 2004:295)

Kin terms, plant parts, human terms and some other nouns (for the list of nouns see Epps 2008:250) - these nouns are obligatorily possessed. They are typically preceded by a proper name, another kin term, or by a subject pronoun, i.e. a morphologically unmarked pronoun (cf. Epps 2008:234). Interestinly, and typologically very unusual, that animal body parts are treated as inalienably possessed, while human body parts are alienably possessed. Additionally, generic human nouns are in the set of obligatorily possessed nouns (cf. Epps 2008:233).
NB: Alienably possessed nouns can occur with the relational prefix or without it. With inalienable nouns the relational prefix is obligatory (cf. Seki 2000:117).

With alienably possessed nouns, the possessor is marked by a genetive suffix; the relative order of possessor-possessed is relatively free. With inanlienably possessed nouns, possessor can be unmarked; the word order in that case is mainly possessor preceding the possessed (cf. Martins 2004:547).

Kinship terms, for instance, muj 'mother', papa 'pather', keke 'grandmother' etc., have to occur with the overt statement of the possessor (either a noun or possessive pronoun). They may occur without being determined by a possessive pronoun only in the syntactic function of a vocative (Larcio Bcelar, p.c. 22.03.2011). Further, there are nouns (mainly denoting body parts) which occur with the neutral prefix i-. These could have been regarded as inalienable nouns, or as nouns with the empty formative root i-. Similar phenomenon in Saban and some other languages of the region (cf. H. van der Voort 2009:366 (Possession, ed. B.McGregor), and H. van der Voort, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:103 (A grammar of Saban )).
There is no fixed formal distinction, though inalienable possession tends to be less marked (Enfield 2007:94).
contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: With alienably possessed nouns: nominal possessor  receives a possessive/benefactive suffix -moki, or if nominal possessor is not realized then person markers receive a possessive/benefactive suffix -moki (not full person pronouns, but person markers). With inalienably possessed nouns: same construction when possessor is nominal  (nominal possessor  receives a possessive/benefactive suffix -moki). different construction when nominal possessor is absent: person markers are prefixed directly to the inalienable possessed noun (cf. van de Kerke 2009:298).
Alienable nouns are normally preceded by an prefix qV preceded by the person marker

With alienable nouns the noun denoting the possessum occurs with a personal possessive prefix followed by a 'relational marker' n-. With inalienale nouns personal possessive prefixes occur directly on the noun (cf. Grondona 1998:66)

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only; inalienable nouns do not occur with a classifier. There are 2 classifiers in Wich:  lo is one is used only with referents denoting all kinds of animals (insects, reptiles, etc. incl.), whereas qa is used with all referents, whether they are inanimates, animates or human.  (cf. Terraza 2009:61).
Inalienable possession is marked by reduplication (cf. Haude 2006:238)
inalienable

In constructions with alienably possessed nouns, the most common construction in use is: [POSSD pers.pos.clitics POSSR], where 'pers.pos.clitics' are so-called Nominal Inflectional Clitics which inflect for person, number and gender of the possessor. Noun denoting the possessor can be omitted, in which case the possessive construction with alienable nouns looks as follows: [POSSD pers.pos.clitics], e.g. nanacam' nucun [fish:species poss:3sg.masc] 'his fish'. (See possessive constructions in Moseten, where possessive marker agrees with the possessed occurs on the possessor and not on the possessed.) In constructions with inalienably possessed noun, the most common strategy to mark possession is to use possessive suffixes which encode person, number and gender of the possessor, e.g. xiri-con xijam [house-3sg.masc m:name] 'Xijam's house', or xiri-con [house-3sg.masc ] 'his house' (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:150,235).
Concluded from available material Certainty: ?
With alienable nouns classifiers are used, this is not the case for inalienable nouns  (Tom and Doris Payne, p.c.). (See also Carlson & Payne 1989 'Genetive classifiers')

In constructions with obligatorily possessed nouns, the head nominal occurs with a personal possessive prefix marking possessor (nominal possessor can also be present). In constructions with non-obligatorily possessed nouns, the head nominal does not occur with any marking: POSSD POSSR (cf. Vidal 2001:291).

Possessive constructions with alienable nouns: either nominal or pronominal possessor is followed by a possessive marker (the possessive/genitive marker occurs with a relational prefix).  In possessive constructions with inalienable nouns the possessive/genitive marker is not used; personal possessive prefix occurs on an inalienably possessed noun either directly (if the noun begins with a consonant) or with a relational prefix (if the noun begins with a vowel) (cf. Alves 2004:48).

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Arauji (2004:102) notes that '[a]lienability is not morphologically distinct in Saban', while this distinction is widespread in Nambikwaran languages. Inanlienable nouns are frequently marked by the prefix a- in those languages. In Saban, all nouns referring to human body parts and animal parts begin with the vowel i or a; on this fact there are several suggestions: possible vestiges of an inalienability morphemes in Proto-Nambikwara (J.Costa, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:102);  an areal feature (H. van der Voort, p.c., referred to in Araujo 2004:103) (cf. Araujo 2004:102).

With alienably possessed nouns the possessive constructions look as follows: [POSSR {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [POSSR POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}], where clitic 'e' may optionally precede or follow the possessed with no change in meaning. In cases of pronominal possessor the construction with alienably possessed nouns is as follows: [pos.pronoun POSSD] (for 1st and 2nd person possessor) and [3rd personal pronoun {poss.clitic 'e'} POSSD] or [3rd personal pronoun POSSD {poss.clitic 'e'}] (for 3rd person possessor). In possessive constructions with kinship terms (inalienably possessed nouns), the construction is similar except that  the poss.clitic 'e' always follows the kinship term and is preceded by an additional suffix which is phonologically determined. Possession of a body part is indicated either by a personal or a possessive pronoun preceding the body part (cf. (Gmez 1990:52-56).

There is no marking on either possessor or possessed with alienable nouns (which is the majority), inalienable nouns are marked by cross-referencing prefixes (the same as agent/subject cross-ref.prefixes occurring on verbs (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:122,483). Besides there is an alternative construction with a cross-referencing prefix + -ya- + possessed clf followed by the possessed noun; this construction is used both with alien. and inalien. nouns (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:134)
(extra n)
Possessive constructions for alienable and inalienable nouns are the same, though a different set of possessive prefixes is used with both types of nouns.

In constructions with alienably possessed nouns, the possessor receives a poss. marker -k(a)te. With inalienably possessed nouns, the possessor is juxtaposed to the possessed with no marking (word order: posser-possed) (cf. Guirardello 1999:17)

NB: Olawsky (2006:350,354) notes that Urarina might had inalienably possessed nouns at an earlier stage, but the feature has been largely lost over time. There are some some traces of inalienability: nouns denoting body parts, kinship terms, some human attributes and a few abstract nouns can occur with a possessive proclitic marking possession instead of free personal pronoun (the use of proclitics or free pronouns are both acceptable).
Certainty: ?

Body parts fall under inalienable possession. In isolated speech, the possessive marker for body parts is always the first person plural form /nusa-/. 'Even when referring to their own body in connected speech, the Mamaind will often revert to the  /nusa-/ form.' (Eberhard 2009:329).
Certainty: ?

The classifier morpheme iba 'domestic animal' is used in possessive constructions with nouns (denoting domestic animals) which cannot be possessed directly (cf. Rose 2003:230).

Nouns denoting animals require the use of the bound root -lo 'animal' occuring on the personal possessive prefix (cf. Grondona 1998:77)

NB: In Wich, classifiers are used in possessive constructions with alienable nouns. There are 2 classifiers:  lo is one is used only with referents denoting all kinds of animals (insects, reptiles, etc. incl.), whereas qa is used with all referents, whether they are inanimates, animates or human. Classifiers can occur as free morphemes or can receive a personal possessive prefix denoting the possessor (cf. Terraza 2009:61). See Mocov where the same classifier lo is used with animals.

In possessive constructions with animals as pets (rather than food, etc) the word aton 'pet' is required, 'which itself is inalienable possessed in the same way as body parts' (Guirardello 1999:77).
What might be called as genitive classifying morphemes should sooner be regarded as generic nouns (nouns modifying nouns) (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

There is a morpheme tiba 'pet' which is used in possessive constructions with nouns denoting domestic animals (cf. van Gijn 2006:117). Tiba is a nominal root receiving a possessive prefix.

Although examples found where the auxiliary verb txa 'to be' can be used (cf. Facundes 2000:296,503), other examples show that the verb is not required: kuku  popuka-ru [man  apurin-M] 'The man is Apurin' (Facundes 2000:504).
The choice for a copular for nominal complements (nan) , adjectives (nan, zan, a?zan, zanik 'become', and kawa) and locatives (nan, zan) overlap (cf. Frank 1990:24)
Ayoreo nouns have 3 forms: base, full and indeterminate, base form occurs without copula, full form with a copula
The use of copula is not obligatory (cf.Seifart 2005:64)
Copula is a suffix attached to the predicate base. In certain conditions (most unmarked situations) copua is not present, a construction of juxtaposition is used (S.Danielsen, p.c.)

(See Guillaume 2008, sections 4.6.3 and 11.1)

Copula is used in constructions with alienable nouns as predicates and personal pronouns as subjects. Copula is not used when subjects are expressed by proper names, or when nominal predicates are inalienably possessed nouns (thus occuring with a personal possessive prefix) (cf. Terraza 2009:66)

tunshuwanka-sl huk general-si ka-rqa 'Tunshuhuanca tait un gnral.'

Copula is usually omitted when the verb is in the present tense, third person, and not bearing aspect. In other cases the use of copula is obligatory (cf. Cole 1982:67). The Q is answered as 'no' since here only present tense clauses are taken into accound and the obligatorily used copulas.
not 3sg

comment: Valenzuela (2003:333) notes that clauses with a missing copula also occur in spontaneous discourse.

No copula with predicative nouns in simple present tense; copular is used with predicative nouns in all other tenses (copula follows the noun) (cf. Galucio 2001:183). See Galucio (2001:184) on copula in Mekens.
clitics

3rd person pronoun ha'e '(s)he/it' can function as a copula; it occurs between the subject NP and the nominal predicate. In case emphasis is put on the identity of the subject NP, the  pers.pronoun ha'e may occur before the two juxtaposed NPs (cf. Gonzlez 2005:215).
Copula is always preceded by the subject (cf. Guirardello 1999:123)
Not obligatory, depends on the semantics of the statement (presentation, class membership, equation, etc) (Meira, p.c.)
In the present tense clauses no copula is used (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:27)
'my sickness'
Adjectives share many properties with nouns. About 40 underived adjectives (Overall 2007:138).

Property concepts are expressed either by classificatory nouns or by intransitive verbs with the notional subject encoded by either subject or object pronominal markers (hareka-no [be.good-1SG.O] 'I am good' (cf. Facundes 2000:281).
The number of adjectives seems small (cf. Frank 1990:19)
Lexemes and derived
Adjectives in Karo constitute an open class (cf. Gabas 1999:61).
Certainty: ?
Property concepts are expressed by verbs by means of a relative clause construction (cf. Nonato 2008:34).

Adjectives of 'class III: derived forms' constitute the largest part of adjective class. They are derived from verbs and nouns by means of the nominalizer -no and/or with the attributive prefix ko- 'ATTR/with' or mo- 'PRIV/without'. The attributive prefix ko- generally derives verbs from nouns. The adjectives are then derived from these verbs by nominalization (cf. Danielsen 2007:168)
The class of adjectives consists of about 50 items. Sakel (2003: 114) mentions that '[n]evertheless, many verbs convey similar notions'.

There are two different classes of adjectives in Cavinea: an open class of predicative adjectives and a closed class of attributive adjectives. Predicative adjectives function only as copula complements (and never as attributive modifers), but they are very often used attributively within (copula) relative clauses, while attributive adjectives function only as NP modifiers (and never predicatively) (cf. Guillaume 2008:61,465). Attributive adjectives constitute a closed class of 16 bare roots which belong to the following 4 semantic groups: dimension, age, color, and physical properties (cf. Guillaume 2008:73). Some of these adjectives are forms which partially overlap with predicative adjective forms for the same meaning. Predicative adjectives can express the same and other adjectival concepts (dimension, age, color, physical properties, human propensities, etc).

Nouns with a definite reference have a distinction between base and full form. Generally adjectives don't have the full form. In other words, the only difference between nouns and so-called adjectives is that the latter have less morphology (like gender/number suffix).
In Tsafiki, 'there is only one, undisputable, underived adjective wa 'big', which is probably related to the coverb owa 'grow' (Dickinson 2002:69)

The class of underived adjectives is very small. Many nominalized verbs serve the function of adjectives (Morse & Maxwell 1999:124). They most resemble nouns, however, noun and adj-s may be distinguished by the classifiers that appear (or fail to appear) on each (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:123,124).

There is a very small closed class of adjectaval roots in Desano that never occur with verbal endings but they do occur with classifiers. The adjectives are: age and dimension type. (Value, color - are verbal roots) (Miller 1999:51,125).

Rose (2003:44) distinguishes 2 classes of items with adjectival semantics: nominoides (human propensity and physical properties of humans; behaviour mainly as nominals) and attributifs (dimension, colour, value; behave like no other word class, need relativizers to modify nouns or to function as arguments, and sometimes need predicativizers to function as predicates). Certainty: ?
Certainty: ?
The class of adjectives is small (M.Crevels, p.c.) Certainty: ?

There is a closed class of 14 adjectives; also there is a derivational process of limited productivity for deriving adjectives from stative verbs (Dixon 2004:75,335). 'Adjectives are very similar to possessed nouns in their grammatical properties' (p.75)
H does not mention A as a class, but she talks about a 'modificador descriptivo' with its own place in the NP.
'Kadiwu does not have adjectives'

comment: Adjectives not separately treated, but they seem to exist as an underived class (2?)

Fleck (2003:462) reports 58 adjective roots in Matss. Matss has a productive adjectivalization process, making the adjective class an open lexical class (which differs however from open classes as nouns and verbs by its relatively few number of roots). Dimension and speed notions are coded by adverbs instead of adjectives. Adjectives can be used as noun modifiers and as copular complements. 'In predicative constructions, adjectives must be clitized with one of a special subset of enclitics ('adjective-modifying enclitics'), which could be considered the adjectival inflections. These enclitics code intensification or de-intensification, large vs. small size (a sort of 'size-agreement comparable to adjectival gender agreement in Romance languages), and derogatory vs. complimentary' (Fleck 2003:462).
Certainty: ?

Share properties with nouns. The question of a separate class of adjectives requires further investigation, as well as the identification of the word class to which the property concepts belong (K.Haude, p.c.). Certainty: ?
A small number underived, but normally with all purpose -o
Certainty: ?

Question is answered as 'nouns' taking into account property concepts used in attributive constructions (property words can be expressed predicatively (as verbs) or attributively (as possessed nouns), with the former being more common (J.Birchall, p.c.)). NB: The notion of adjective is expressed by possessed nouns, derived nouns and noun clauses preceding the noun in a possessed NP (Everett & Kern 1997:152)
Not clear whether these are adjectives or stative verbs. See attributive use (ex.21a) on p.65. See Adelaar with Muysken (2004:136) for other examples. Certainty: ?

These adjectives have properties of nouns, i.e. they inflect for gender and number. One feature which adjectives do not share with nouns is 'possession' (cf. Vidal 2001:107). 'Some adjectives denoting 'dimension' inflect for gender and number, others inflect only for number, the masculine and the feminine having exactly the same form' (Vidal 2001:109).

Property concepts are mainly expressed by verbal roots which receive the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (cf. Girn 2008:167,233). However, there seem to be a small group of words expressing quality which do not take the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (cf. Girn 2008:155).
See forth.article by S.Floyd arguing there is a class of adjectives in Ec.Q. Certainty: ?
Despite Cole (1982:99) statement that adjectives and nouns belong to one class, there are reasons (syntactic distribution?) to believe that Q. has a separate class of adjectives. Certainty: ?
Property concepts are expressed by verbs

comment: There is a difference though between verbal 'adjectives' and verbs: reduplication process. Namely, verb reduplication 'makes the action repetitive while verbal adjective reduplication intensifies the qualities expressed by the verbal adjective'. (Araujo 2004:163).
Adjectives are bound roots which have to occur with the 3rd person prefix.
Any adjective can be used without a nominal head in a NP (cf. Aikhenvald 2003:72)

Gonzlez (2005:128) notes that Tapiete does not have a clear lexical category adjective. Instead, adjectives share with inactive verbs a number of verbal morphological features such as the set of person markers, aspect, as well as derivational morphology as the nominalizing suffix -wa ~ -a 'NMLZ'. Certainty: ?
If we define adjectives as having the prototypical function of modification, then there is no class of adjectives (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
There are no underived adjectives; the words which have function usually assigned to adjectives can be devided into noun-like and verb-like (cf. Olawsky 2006:308).

Romero-Figeroa (1997:42,49) mentions that there is no clear-cut distinction between nouns and adjectives. Warao nouns may function as (adjective-like) attributives modifying other nouns in NPs, they are always posthead in that case. [OK: However, not much information/example available to determine whether adjectives are indeed indistinguishable from nouns.] Certainty: ?

Classifiers function much like adjectives in M. (cf. Eberhard 2009:330). Typical adjectival qualities are expressed by verbs. These take the same morphology as verbs and behave like intransitive verbs in the language. Such verbal roots are not found on their own to modify a noun (Eberhard 2009:364).

There are two different classes of adjectives in Cavinea: an open class of predicative adjectives and a closed class of attributive adjectives. Predicative adjectives function only as copula complements (and never as attributive modifers), but they are very often used attributively within (copula) relative clauses, while attributive adjectives function only as NP modifiers (and never predicatively) (cf. Guillaume 2008:61,465). Attributive adjectives constitute a closed class of 16 bare roots which belong to the following 4 semantic groups: dimension, age, color, and physical properties (cf. Guillaume 2008:73). Some of these adjectives are forms which partially overlap with predicative adjective forms for the same meaning. Predicative adjectives can express the same and other adjectival concepts (dimension, age, color, physical properties, human propensities, etc).
tutu ; grande

These adjectives have properties of nouns, i.e. they inflect for gender and number. One feature which adjectives do not share with nouns is 'possession' (cf. Vidal 2001:107). comment: Definitely not verbs
Not treated as such, but some examples: 245

The four native numerals  and most quantifiers belong to the class of verb-like adjectives. The non-native numerals from 'five' onwards have properties of noun-like adjectives (cf. Haude 2006:113,114).

There is one compound verb that expresses the notion of cardinal numerals used as an attribute: xica' pe 'to be alone', used as 'one'. It is always used to express 'one', that is, the Portuguese numeral um is never used. There is another compound verb, tucu caracan 'to face each other', that used to be used as 'two' but is rarely used nowadays; rather the Portuguese numeral dois is used. Dois 'two' (masculine form of Portuguese 'two') is used irrespective of the gender of the noun it modifies. New numerals take the Portuguese form and occur as a simple verb. Numerals (both 'ON and loan numerals) appear in verbal position with the syntax of intransitive verbs. (Everett & Kern 1997:347).

Numerals are expressed by verbal roots which receive the attributive (nominalizing) prefix -i (have exactly the same construction as with verbal roots expressing property concepts) (cf. Girn 2008:297).
nouny-adjectives (Simeon Floyd, p.c.)

Miller (1999:125) notes that '[t]here are virtually no predicate adjectives in Desano, as adjectival concepts are normally expressed by nominalizing a stative verb'.
, a prefix kya- is added
adjective-like words are treated as adverbs, see D79:34,42
3sg not
An example in Dixon (2004:339)
Unlike predicate nominals, predicate adj-s never take a copula (cf Epps 2008:771)
The language has no adjectives, 3sg-N 'her beauty' constructions
see p.575
Certainty: ?

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Adjectival concepts are expressed by stative verbs in L.
Adjectivalized nouns and verbs can only occur in predicative constructions, and not in attributive (cf. Fleck 2003:508). See also cf. Fleck (2003:466).
There is no copula verb in Mocov (cf. Grondona 1998:15)
Concluded from examples (cf. Jung 2008:144). Certainty: ?
Vidal (2001:293) notes that adjectives always follow the noun they modify. If an adjective precedes the noun, then it functions as a predicate and is not part of the same NP with the noun.
I good I (repeticion del pronombre)
best bet

Copula is usually omitted when the verb is in the present tense, third person, and not bearing aspect. In other cases the use of copula is obligatory (cf. Cole 1982:67). The Q is answered as 'no' since here only present tense clauses are taken into accound and the obligatorily used copulas.
not 3sg
As in other dialects, 3sg not expressed, carrier INFL
not 3sg
3sg copula deleted

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Property concepts are expressed by verbs.
adjectival static verbs
Certainty: ?

Gonzlez (2005:128) notes that Tapiete does not have a clear lexical category adjective. Instead, adjectives share with inactive verbs a number of verbal morphological features such as the set of person markers, aspect, as well as derivational morphology as the nominalizing suffix -wa ~ -a 'NMLZ'.
Copula can be used, however, in many (not all) examples given the copula is absent (cf. Guirardello 1999:37), examples with copula used can be found on p. 45.
Not obligatory, depnds on the semantics of the statement (presentation, class membership, equation, etc) (Meira, p.c.)
Adjectives take predicator -kasi
In the present tense clauses no copula is used (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:27)
'A relativized plural form of the copular [...] may modify the noun; functionally this is a plural marker' (Overall 2007:124).
Plural marking is optional. Number marking is absent if a noun is modified by a numeral or a quantifier (cf. CP&CC 2009:188)

There are two pairs of morphological number markers: -wako-ru ('-PL-F') and -wako-ro ('-PL-M'), and -nu-ru ('-PL-F')  and -nu-ro ('-PL-M'). The forms -wako-ru and -wako-ro are used only with nouns referring to humans. The morphemes marking gender (ru and ro) are obligatory and can't be omitted. When the plural marker occurs on the noun stem which is already marked for gender (the same gender markers ru and ro), the plural marker still occurs with the gender markers. The second pair of plural markers (-nu-ru and -nu-ro) can occur on nouns for animate and inanimate referents. Different from the other number marker, -nu is more often used with the gender markers but can be used without it. Facundes (2000:262) notes that it still needs to be verified if the dropping of the gender marker is restricted to nouns which already have a gender marker in their base.

NB: Frank (1990:56) mentions once that '[r]eduplication indicates plurality of an object'. This is menitoned with respect to reduplication of locational words: 'when referring to a book on a table, the proper locational word is ipa but for a number of books is ipap'. (Jan Rijkhoff (2002:152) includes Ika as marking plural by reduplication of a verb in his discussion on quantifying modifiers).

There is a collective marker pu which can be used only with nouns denoting human beings (cf. Smeets 2008:72). Additionally there is a distribuitve suffix -ke  'each', e.g. fia-ke e [old-DISTR human] 'old people' (cf. Adelaar with Muysken 2004:522).

Plural enclitic =to? occurs at the end of the NPs. There are a few lexicalized constructions where the plurality of the referents is somehow intrinsic, and the plural enclitic is part of the lexicalized word and it does not occur in the end of the NP as it normally does: pi=to? c [foot=PL big] 'big feet' (cf. Gabas 1999:74,76).
Suffix -naka (cf. CP&CC 2009:188)

Plural is marked on the noun mainly by the suffix doge, or by some of its allomorphs with a restricted use: -e is the plural marker used nouns denoting animals, -mage is the plural marker used with kinship nouns, -ge occurs on pronouns (cf. Nonato 2008:50). Crowell (1979:223) notes that inanimate nouns can receive a plural marker -doge if the speaker wishes to make it clear that more than one item is involved. Nonato (2008:53) mentions that some nouns have to receive a singular marker d to signal singular reading.
Danielsen (2007:131) refers to the plural marker -nev as a phrasal suffix; this plural morpheme does not cause any stress shift; however, it only attaches to the last element of the NP.

The plural can be marked by the clitic in or by reduplication of the nominal root. There are two types of reduplication in Mosetn: global reduplication and partial reduplication. Global reduplication appears in very few cases, and the use of the plural clitic in is preferred. Partial reduplication is used to express 'distributed plurality': to express that entities are distributed over a certain area (cf. Sakel 2003:66).
There are two plural markers: =kwana (used with any type of noun) and =ekana (used with kinship nouns possessed by first and second persons) (cf. Guillaume 2008:74).
usi-kunas ; las casas
NB: there are distinct plural enclitics the use of whih depend on the gender of the speaker (=kana 'pl.male speech', =nu 'pl. female speech') (see Vallejos 2010:160).

Bare nouns of class 1 (mass nouns and generic terms) lack plural forms. Class 2 nouns (concrete nouns (appearing alone or functioning as cls), deverbal concrete, and deverbal abstract nouns)) can occur with plural marker (-A) on a bare stem or on stem+cls. Animate nouns have a different form of plural suffix (-wA) (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:74-77).
There are different plural suffixes for animates and inanimates, in addition to several other irregular ways of pluralizing (cf. Miller 1999:52)
The same clitic -kom is used on nouns, personal pronouns, demonstratives (cf. Rose 2003:160).

Plurality is obligatory only in the verb phrase, and is marked optionally in the subject of the NP. Plural marking on the noun phrase only becomes obligatory if large numbers are being talked about (cf. Mortensen 1999:42).
but mainly 'group'
Concluded from available examples
Not obligatory
There are two exceptions: umu 'man', umu'ke 'men', and t'iyaya'tya 'girl', t'iyaya'tye 'girls' (M.Crevels, p.c.).

Number is not marked on the noun itself but by pronominal cross-referencing on the verb. The sg/nsg distinction in 3rd p pronouns only applies for animates; all inanimates have zero pronominal cross-referencing. However, the verbal suffix -rawa 'nsg.fem' is used with all types of fem.nouns, both animate and inanimate (cf. Dixon 2004:75,289). See p.75 for the related distinctions shown lexically.
Suffixes as one method, and also nasalization of the final consonant for kinship terms (see Seki 2000:59).
Singular/plural distinction is found in the set of pronouns and pronominal prefixes attached to the verb (Everett 2006:296).
Number marking is found only on personal pronouns (cf. Curnow 1997:85)

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Plural enclitic -bo can optionally attach to any noun that refers to a human indicating either a set of people in a group, a catergory of people in general, or multiple people acting separately. In order to specify collective meaning, the verbal suffixes -cueded or -beded are used, optionally with or without the plural enclitic -bo (cf. Fleck 2003:273). The plural enclitic also occurs (less commonly) on non-human referents to specify a heterogeneous category (cf. Fleck 2003:272).

The plural suffix -ipi can be used with all nouns, it denotes four or more entities. The plural suffix is added to the paucal form of the noun. There is also another suffix (-sat ~ -šat) which is used with nouns denoting plants, trees, or parts thereof, and has a collective meaning (cf. Grondona 1998:61)

Collective marker is morphologically different from the plural markers in Wich. Interestingly, plural and collective markers can co-occur. Terraza (2009:88) notes that in Toba (Guaycuruan), this is also the case, with the only difference that in Toba collective and plural can co-occur in certain contexts.
Normally on N but if N is modified by A , it occurs on A

NB: Plural on nouns occurs only in DATIVE (noun in DAT either preceded or not by a numeral). Otherwise nouns referring to plural entities do not have a number marking, neither when they are preceded by a numeral (cf. Jung 2008:131).
The same marker could be interpreted as the marker to mark more of the same kind, collective meaning, and the associative meaning (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
Referred to as 'collective' by Vidal, this number marker can also occur on mass-nouns (cf. Vidal 2001:94-96).
Roots ending in vowel spanish -s, roots ending in consonant -s or -kuna, also combinations of both
wambra-n-kuna-ta 'a sus hijos'
Plural marker -kuna (cf. Cole 1982:128).
Plural marker is expressed by a prefix; it occurs on human nouns (cf. Alves 2004:48). See Alves (2004:48) for distinct markers for humans vs. non-human referents.

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Plural of nouns denoting human and animate referents is formed by postposing the reduced form of the 3rd person plural animate pronoun /pIk/. Nouns denoting plants and inanimate objects usually take the partitive-collective suffix -k to mark plural (cf. Gmez 1990:79-80). E.g.: ~canam pIk [Yanam AN.PL] 'Yanam people', carekep mamo-k [two eye-INAN.PL] 'two eyes' (cf. Gmez 1990:79,74). [Comment: compare with Movima where plural marking is done by so-called referential elements].

Plural enclitic -bo (cf. Valenzuela 2003:203-4). The plural marker cannot be used with non-count nouns (nouns denoting nature entities, meteorological forces, food and drink products, some body parts like 'body hair', 'eyebrow', 'beard', etc., and some nouns denoting cultural items).
The collective marker can be used for sg vs pl distinction (cf. Galucio 2001:29, p.c.)

The suffix -reta or its shortened form -re (cf. Gonzlez 2005:101). The same marker can be used to convey a collective meaning; it seems also to have an associative reading (e.g. lsa-re [elsa-PL] ' Elsa's family) (cf. Gonzlez 2005:101).
Plural morpheme wan. 'The pluralizers occur in an NP after the element they modify (noun, pronoun) but if there is no head noun, the pluralizer then stands by itself in the NP' (Guirardello 1999:55).
The same marker could be interpreted as the marker to mark more of the same kind, collective meaning, and the associative meaning (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
concluded from examples, see Da Cruz 2011:266-267
'The occurence of plural markers is optional when plurality is already indicated somewhere else in the same phrasal construction'  (cf. Facundes 2000:262)
can be realized on modifying adjective
nothing said about it
Certainty: ?

Plural marker is obligatory on all nominal expression, 'with the exception of non-count nouns (which do not combine with number markers at all) and nominal expressions that are formed with the general inanimate class marker (where number marking is optional)'. There  are morphologically distinct plural markers for nouns, numerals, and other nominal expressions and relative clauses (cf. Seifart 2005:56).
Only animate nouns are pluralized regularly, inanimate nouns can receive a plural marker -doge if the speaker wishes to make it clear that more than one item is involved (cf. Crowell 1979:223).
In tendency

'Non-human objects are often represented as singular in number, as opposed to humans and higher animates. The latter includes animals which in the mythology appear in the shape of humans' (Sakel 2003:68). 'Things are only pluralised when there is a focus on the plurality - they don't have to be marked by the (nominal) plural marker. Yet, there is such marking in the verbal cross-reference ending' (J.Sakel, p.c. email 19.04.2011). When nouns are modified by a numeral, there is no plural marker (this is also the case for human nouns), e.g. paerae w 'two sons' (cf. Sakel 2003:68).
Guillaume (2008:480) notes that '[a]lthough number tends to be marked in many cases, it is not an obligatory category of the NP'.  In many examples both plural and dual markers are present.
Definite nouns require plural
If a noun is modified by a numeral, number marking is optional (see Vallejos 2010:265). Certainty: ?
The plural marker is not obligatory with human nouns but is used commonly (cf. Dickinson 2002:57)
in fact it is optional on 'human nouns'
Certainty: ?

The group of human nouns are subdivided into 2 groups: nouns inherently fem or masc, the other group comprises human nouns which consist of a root plus a suffix indicating gender and number (masc sg, fem sg, anim pl) (cf.Miller 1999:22,53). The plurals for kinship terms are irregular, see Miller (1999:53). The group of non-human animate nouns is subdivided into 2 groups: one consisting of inherently plural nouns requiring singularizing suffix to refer to a single entity, and the other group consisting of nouns which take the plural marker for animates (cf. Miller 1999:23,52). The group of inanimate nouns is subdivided into 3 groups: mass nouns which are non-countable, inherently plural and taking a singularizing suffix when used in reference to a single entity, and the 3rd class of nouns taking the regular plural marker for inanimates (cf. Miller 1999:23,52). Certainty: ?
Plural marker is optional on all nouns, also when modified by a numeral higher than 2 (cf. Rose 2003:216).

Plurality is obligatory only in the verb phrase, and is marked optionally in the subject of the NP. Plural marking on the noun phrase only becomes obligatory if large numbers are being talked about (cf. Mortensen 1999:42). When a noun is modified by a numeral, plural number is also optional (Licht 1999:83).
Obligatory on pronouns 1PL, 2PL
Not when modified by numeral
Example (309) p.121 for modification by a numeral
Certainty: ?

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: When a noun is modified by a numeral, the number marking is not obligatory with animate referents and often absent with inanimate referents. When numeral is not present, than there is a stong tendency to realize the number marking on human referents, less on non-human animates, and much less on inanimates (S. van de Kerke, p.c. 27.01.2011).
Not explicitly stated, but it looks like obligatory marking

Plural enclitic -bo can optionally attach to any noun that refers to a human indicating either a set of people in a group, a catergory of people in general, or multiple people acting separately. In order to specify collective meaning, the verbal suffixes -cueded or -beded are used, optionally with or without the plural enclitic -bo (cf. Fleck 2003:273). The plural enclitic also occurs (less commonly) on non-human referents to specify a heterogeneous category (cf. Fleck 2003:272).

Not clear whether the use of plural marker with nouns denoting plural entities is simply possible or obligatory. Grondona (1998:61) notes that the plural suffix can be used with all nouns. Number marking is optional with a noun modified by a numeral (cf. Grondona 1998:91). Certainty: ?
Plural marker is obligatory on all nouns. When combined with a numeral or quantifier, the plural marker is absent (Vernica Nercesian, p.c. via Rik van Gijn).
Much more frequent on animates than on inanimates, and much more frequent on humans. In other words, the higher on hierarchy the more likely is the use of the plural marker. (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
Certainty: ?

Not clear whether the use of plural marker with nouns denoting plural entities is simply possible or obligatory. See example (p. 106) for agreement in number. There are examples of numeral for 'two' and of quantifiers modifiying nouns where nouns do occur with paucal (in case of numeral for 'two') or plural/collective marker (in case of quantifiers). Certainty: ?
It is not clear whether plural marker is obligatory on (non-human) nouns when modified by a numeral higher than 1.
Used more frequently with animates than with inanimates. NB: in Cuzco Quechua, the plural marker is obligatory absent when a noun is modified by a numeral (p.c. Pieter Muysken)
Not when modified by numeral
Not when modified by numeral
Data limited
NB: 'Plural marking is obligatory except when a noun is preceded by a numeral' (Cole 1982:128).
Not when modified by numeral
'mass' interpretation leads to singular
unless 'groups' come into play
It is not clear if the plural prefix is obligatory on human nouns, or whether it can occur exclusively on human nouns. Certainty: ?

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: Plural of nouns denoting human and animate referents is formed by postposing the reduced form of the 3rd person plural animate pronoun /pIk/. Nouns denoting plants and inanimate objects usually take the partitive-collective suffix -k to mark plural (cf. Gmez 1990:79-80). The co-occurrence of the partitive-collective suffix with a numeral is optional (cf. Gmez 1990:122). Certainty: ?

NB: There is obligatory marking for all nouns, regardless of animacy status at the beginning of a narrative or discourse, after that (once they have been established as topics) it becomes optional. When combined with a numeral or quantifier, plural marking on the noun is absent  (Gonzlez, p.c. via Rik van Gijn).

See note. Guirardello (1999:56) mentions that the plural marker is used only with animate referents, its use with inanimates is regarded ungrammatical. There is, however, an other factor which plays a role: with Dative NPs, the plural marker or the collective marker is required with human nouns, and seems to be optional with non-human animates (the presence of a quantifier or a numeral would be enough to give a non-singular meaning). With inanimate nouns the use of the plural morpheme is not possible (collective marker can be used) (cf. Guirardello 1999:58-61).
Much more frequent on animates than on inanimates, and much more frequent on humans. In other words, the higher on hierarchy the more likely is the use of the plural marker. (Srgio Meira, p.c.)

When a noun is modified by a numeral, it can optionally be marked for plural. It is more common to mark the noun in combination with a numeral for plural if it refers to a human. In contrast, if the noun modified by a numeral does not refer to a human, it is unlikely to be marked for plural (cf. Olawsky 2006:367).
The plural suffix is used only when the speaker wants to emphasize plurality, both with animate and inanimate referents.
Plural marker can be omitted if plurality is clear from the context, e.g. a noun is modified by a numeral (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:73).
Number marking is optional when a noun is modified by a numeral (see da Cruz 2011:269)
A complicated system of plurality marking, there is a split in pl.mark. within the inanimate nouns, whereas all animate nouns mark plural (van Gijn 2006:95)
prefix caa- forms a pair/two of, but it is rare
Certainty: ?

Enclitic =ekatse 'DL' (cf. Guillaume 2008:74). Guillaume (2008:480) notes that '[a]lthough number tends to be marked in many cases, it is not an obligatory category of the NP'.  In many example both plural and dual markers are present.
Huaca? Lexeme B 48, ex. 4.50

NB: About 10 stance verbs have suppletive forms for sg, du, or pl. Number is not marked on the noun itself but by pronominal cross-referencing on the verb. The sg/nsg distinction in 3rd p pronouns only applies for animates; all inanimates have zero pronominal cross-referencing. However, the verbal suffix -rawa 'nsg.fem' is used with all types of fem.nouns, both animate and inanimate (cf. Dixon 2004:75). See p.75 for the related distinctions shown lexically.

Paucal and dual marking is found only on verbs (cf. Olawsky 2006:374).

Optional. The same element occurs on nouns and verbs; used only with humans and animals (cf. van der Voort 2004:540)
There is a collective marker pu which can be used only with nouns denoting human beings (cf. Smeets 2008:72).
The plural marker has a collective meaning (V.Galucio, p.c.)
It is not clear though if the same plural markers can have a collective meaning as well.

taqa and plural marking
The same marker which marks plurality Certainty: ?
Certainty: ?
When the plural marker occurs on nouns denoting animals and inanimates, it tends to have a collective reading (cf. Dickinson 2002:58)
suffix -nacu (loan from Quechua?)

M&M (1999:74) mention that an inanimate noun + PL without a classifier (what normally is the case) has a meaning of collectives. In this sense, the same plural marker as for marking plural is used to denote collectiveness.
There is the clitic -kom which may mark collectiveness. F.Rose notes that collectiveness is rather expressed by zero (p.c. 23.03.2011).
Probably the plural marker has sooner a collective reading (?). Certainty: ?
Plural marking used as such
The use of collective marker is restricted to human referents when the focus is on a group, and to animal nouns or items integral to the culture.
Plural
The plural clitic can also function as a collective marker (cf. Epps 2008:192)
kat, found in the other guaykuruan ll., is not mentioned
Collective meaning is expressed by a different marker than plural meaning (cf. Martins 2004:404).

NB: sort of collective. There is one suffix, the Collective action suffix tuzpa, which can be attached to nouns to show something similar to number. Rather than simply marking multiple referents, the suffix marks that the referents form a coherent group, additionally, the group has to have been acting together to perform some process (Curnow 1997:131).

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: NB: the use is very limited. There is a collective morpheme kat, which is used with nouns denoting trees (primarily with trees having edible fruits) (S. van de Kerke, p.c.)
Collective only for plants/trees

Probably the plural enclitic -bo can also indicate collectiveness. There are also verbal suffixes which specify collective semantics (the verbal suffix optionally occur with or without the plural enclitic -bo) (cf. Fleck 2003:273).

Additionally to the paucal and plural suffix, there is suffix -sat ~ -šat, which is used with nouns denoting plants, trees, or parts thereof, and has a collective meaning. The collective suffix is added to the singular form of the noun (note that the plural suffix is added to the paucal form of the noun) (cf. Grondona 1998:61)

Collective marker is morphologically different from the plural markers in Wich. Interestingly, plural and collective markers can co-occur. Terraza (2009:88) notes that in Toba (Guaycuruan), this is also the case, with the only difference that in Toba collective and plural can co-occur in certain contexts.
Plural marker has a collective reading as well (K.Haude, p.c.).
There are several collective particles; they can occur preceding most nominal construction (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:156,287).
Collective marker can be used exclusively in reference to human beings; it can occur on nouns, pronouns, adjectives, and adverbials (cf. Jung 2008:132).
The same marker could be interpreted as the marker to mark more of the same kind, collective meaning, and the associative meaning. (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
There is a collective marker -sat, which is used for trees and the noun for lake, and the collective marker (or plural marker?) pi for the rest of the nouns (Vidal 2001:94).
The plural suffix -ot can be used to express collectiveness (cf. Girn 2008:193).
Collective marker -nti(n) (Pieter Muysken, p.c.). Pedro Plaza Martnez (2009:230) mentions that reduplication is often used for marking collective.
There is no distinction between collective and distributive plurals (cf. Cole 1982:128).
There is a collective suffix -je which can occur on demonstratives (cf. Alves 2004:84). However, it is not clear where its occurrence is limited to dem-s. Certainty: ?

comment: Certainty: ?

Plural of nouns denoting human and animate referents is formed by postposing the reduced form of the 3rd person plural animate pronoun /pIk/. Nouns denoting plants and inanimate objects usually take the partitive-collective suffix -k to mark plural (cf. Gmez 1990:79-80). E.g.: ~canam pIk [Yanam AN.PL] 'Yanam people', carekep mamo-k [two eye-INAN.PL] 'two eyes' (cf. Gmez 1990:79,74).
NB: The plural marker -bo has the function of a collective (cf. Valenzuela 2003:219).
The same morpheme can be also used for sg vs pl distinction (cf. Galucio 2001:29, p.c.)

The same marker (-reta or -re) can be used to mark plurality and to convey a collective meaning; it seems also to have an associative reading (e.g. lsa-re [elsa-PL] ' Elsa's family) (cf. Gonzlez 2005:101).

The same marker as the plural marker (-fo 'various': it can be used both with nominals and verbs in past tenses, suffix -nõ 'and others' is used only with nominals. The latter might sooner be considered as associative marker) (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:73).

comment: NB: There are no personal pronouns in Wari', there are only emphatic pronouns which may appear alone or in apposition to a noun in left dislocation, but may not appear alone as arguments of the verb (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:303,310). The emphatic pronouns have incl/excl distinction, gender distinction in 3rd person sg. and pl., and number distinction within all pronouns (sg/pl). The Q is answered for the emphatic pronouns.
Unlike in other Quechua languages, IQ does not have incl. vs. excl. distinction (Cole 1982:130).
But the inclusive looses terrain
Some kinship terms, and 5 other nouns encode gender as part of their meaning (cf. Overall 2007:124).

All nouns are either masc. or fem. for the purpose of cross-referencing with other elements within a syntactic construction. Within the NP, gender seems to be encoded on numeral 'one' used as a nominal modifier  and adnominal demonstratives. Majority of the nouns are not marked for gender, it is expressed on the verb by a cross-referencing suffix showing M/F gender of the object noun  (cf. Facundes 2000:218). Morphological gender marking on the noun itself is restricted to kinship terms and other nouns denoting humans; it is also used with the word for 'dog' (cf. Facundes 2000:222)
Personal pronouns do not have a gender distinction either (cf. Frank 1990:26)
Realized by general class markers

'Gender is an inherent catagory in Baure, and it is mainly biological, not grammatical. Only feminine animates are considered as grammatically feminine, and all other nouns are masculine' (Danielsen 1997:116). Gender is not formally expressed on the noun, but is realized by agreement in cross-referencing clitics, and personal, possessive and demonstrative pronouns (only in the 3sg).

Feminine and masculine. Human females are in the fem.gender and human males are in the masculine gender; in most other cases the assignment of gender is arbitrary. Genders are inherent to nouns are only realized on other constituents on the NP (cf. Sakel 2003:69).
masc and fem
NB: the q is answered as 'none' since in K-K, not the gender of the entity that one is talking about is grammatically expressed but the gender of the speaker (see Vallejos 2010:200).
Only within 1SG pronouns (masc and fem)=> typologically very unusual (see Corbett 1991, Gender)
Realized as gender/number suffixes, which may also be analysed as classifier morphemes (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:77) Certainty: ?

'Human nouns are inherently either fem or masc. The masc nouns usually end in i (OK: doorhalen) and the fem nouns in o' (Miller 1999:22). Realized as gender/number suffixes (cf. Miller 1999:35) Certainty: ?
Animate vs. Inanimate

Fem is an unmarked term form. Gender is not shown in the form of a noun but by agreement with other items, both within NP and outside NP. Nouns referring to humans have gender according to the sex of the referent; non-human animates have a fixed gender (~85% being masc) (cf. Dixon 2004:284). Within an NP gender is marked on the adjectives bite/biti 'small' and one/owa 'another' (they function both as adjectives and as nouns), the interrogative hibaka/hibake 'who' shows gender, and nominal demonstratives (e.g. haaha/haahi 'this') (cf. Dixon 2004:286).
Gender is expressed only lexically (cf. Martins 2004:129)

contributed_datapoint: Simon van de Kerke and Olga Krasnoukhova 2011-08-11

comment: -I/-E distinguishes between semantic gender but also expesses syntactic gender used with demonstratives, only in singular
Masculine and femine gender is not marked overtly on the noun, but on demonstratives and on most adjectives, which must agree in gender with the head noun they modify (cf. Grondona 1998:48).
Concluded from material; personal pronouns do not have gender distinctions either.
Encoded by 'referential elements' morphologically realized as free forms. Humans are marked either masc or fem, all non-human referents are marked as neuter (cf. Haude 2006:148)

Fem (human females only), masc (human males or certain animals, fish and bird species), neuter (most plants and inanimate objects). Nouns are not marked for gender or humanness/non-humanness; these features are distinguished semantically and/or realized via agreement elsewhere in the clause (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:290).
1st and 2nd p pronouns show masc/fem gender distinction (cf. Jung 2008:133).
Animate vs. Inanimate (?)
There are markers indicating gender. However, it is not clear whether all nouns have an inherent gender. Most of Pilag nouns are not overtly marked for gender (cf. Vidal 2001:88). Certainty: ?
'In Spanish borrowings gender is often preserved (as a lexical property of the borrowed noun)', e.g. tiyu/tiya from to/ta 'uncle/aunt' (Cole 1982:129).

There is an affix -ta, which is used to mark the female gender, the male gender being unmarked. When used in reference to humans, the female marker typically attaches to the 'nimal/human' classifier. When it is not preceded by the animate classifier, the marker can take various senses: to specify a nominal as being a mother, or as being large, or as being dangerous (Eberhard 2009:340).
There are classifying morphemes encoding fem and masc.gender (cf. van der Voort 2004:133)

NB: In Ika, there is a minimal system of noun categorization, definted by the physical shape of the objects, which involves only nouns referring to concrete objects and this system is only relevant in locational sentences. 'Existential and locative clauses make use of noun class indicator plus copula to indicate existence or location.' (cf. Frank 1990:53) OK: the impression is that the cls morphemes might sooner add some semantic load to the copula, specifying it. Ika has a number of classifying verbs, the choice of which depends on the properties of the argument. Copula may be semantically colored too.

comment: Classifiers are not obligatory; if they occur they occur right after the classified noun. In case noun is modified by an adjective, the classifier obligatorily occurs after the noun and after the adjective (in concord) (cf. Gabas 1999:215). Classifiers are used in 3 basic types of construction: a) with a head noun [N+CL], b) in possessive constructions with inalienable nouns [N+N+CL],  c) in compounds [N+CL+N] (cf. Gabas 1999:215).
nouns are divided into possessable and non-possessable, the latter have to be preceded by a classifier

Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only. There are 4 classifiers in Bororo (-ke 'food', -aku 'domesticated animal', -imo 'adornment', -o 'general') (cf. Crowell 1979:215).

Guillaume (2008:409) reports a closed class of 100-150 members, which does not accept borrowed or derived terms. Hein van der Voort (p.c.) points out that these forms which are referred to by Guillaume (2008:409) as 'e-nouns' are in fact very similar to constructions in Kwaza, Movima and some other languages of the area, and are in fact classifiers which are obligatorily suffixed to the empty root 'e-' (Guillaume (2008:409) referres to e- as 'noun prefixes'). The majority of the forms which can be treated as classifiers (Hein van der Voort p.c.) 'have more than two syllables and can form independent phonological words even if they do not take affixes (whether the e-prefix or a derivational affix) or if they are not compounded with another root'. However, 5 forms are monosyllabic (Guillaume 2008:412)
'Classifiers are required for all numerals except man 'one' when they occur with concrete nouns' (Dickinson 2002:75)
At least 150 clf (Morse & Maxwell 1999:73)
There is only one (?) classifier morpheme iba 'domestic animal' which is used in possessive constructions with nouns which cannot be possessed directly (cf. Rose 2003:230).
No cls mentioned.

There seem to be locative classificatory suffixes see (Aikh.2000:175 'Classifiers'), (Derbyshire 1999:43, in Dixon and Aikhenvald 1999 'The Amazonian Languages')
