comment: Classifiers are used in constructions with alienably possessed nouns only; inalienable nouns do not occur with a classifier. There are 2 classifiers in Wich:  lo is one is used only with referents denoting all kinds of animals (insects, reptiles, etc. incl.), whereas qa is used with all referents, whether they are inanimates, animates or human. Classifiers can occur as free morphemes or can receive a personal possessive prefix denoting the possessor (cf. Terraza 2009:61).
Classifiers for tens (numbers)

Pilag has a set of class markers (some of these are used for derivational purposes), and a set of 6 classifiers. The classifiers can occur with count and mass nouns, they can stand by themselves or attach to demonstrative stems. Semantically, they can be divided into two groups: a) positional cls (vert.extended, horiz.extended, non-extended), and b) deictic cls (coming/proximal, going away/past, absent/distal) (cf. Vidal 2001:112-113).
There are seven classifiers in the language, all denoting a physical property. Classifiers are quite frequent, however, not obligatory (cf. Araujo 2004:114).

There are suffix-like elements which may be the remnants of a formally productive classifier system. There are 6 morphemes (kok 'root', sik 'plant', kik 'fruit', mok 'seed', si 'skin', I 'liquid'. Goodwin Gmez (1990:120) does not treat them as classifiers, whereas the recent data suggest that there are classifiers in Niman and throughout the Yanomami family (Gale Goodwin Gmez, p.c. 07.02.2012).  For the list of groups of nouns with these elements, see Goodwin Gmez (1990:120).

There are two morphemes  'pet' and 'food'; these are used in possessive constructions with nouns which cannot be possessed directly. Classifiers are suffxed to the (pro)noun denoting the possessor (V.Galucio, p.c.)
I doubt whether this is really noun classes, very meager, it may be compounds, only 'trees' M 104
What might be called as genetive classifying morphemes should sooner be regarded as generic nouns (nouns modifying nouns) (Srgio Meira, p.c.)
Concluded from material.

Eberhard (2009:330) notes that classifiers is a crucial component in the morphology of Nambikwaran languages. Mamaind has the largest set of classifiers (24) among the N. languages. There is a small set of classifiers which can also function as noun roots. These take noun affixation as any noun, do not requiring any preceding nominal (Eberhard 2009:335).
Not in grammar
There is a morpheme tiba 'pet' which is used in possessive constructions with nouns denoting domestic animals (cf. van Gijn 2006:117). Tiba is a nominal root receiving a possessive prefix.

There are only three numerals to which classifiers have to be attached. The numerals above three are borrowed from Spanish and they are used with a classifier as well. Classifiers are mainly realized as suffixes, though the numeral one is a circumfix in Baure, so the classifier one the classifiers takes the form of an infix.

Gender is marked in all personal pronouns except 1sg, 2sg, 1pl.incl. (F.Seifart, p.c.). Gender distinctions are made in the set of dual and plural polysyllabic personal pronouns, monosyllabic pro-s do not have the distinction (cf. Seifart 2005:55)

Postpositions in Tehuelche are of two kinds: those which agree in gender with the noun, and those which are invariable (cf. Fernndez Garay 1998:297).

Animate vs. Inanimate
There is no gender/sex distinction, though there is animacy distinction (see Dixon 2004:77)
Only in singular

In Kano, the specification of gender can optionally occur with 'oj' 3S and  'ojte' 3PP, with the posposition of the free forms 'vo' for MASC and  'nake' FEM. It is not obligatory, but optional. Marking MASC  occurs with low frequency. Thus, if the speaker wants to avoid ambiguity, the most common is the marking FEM. However, if there are two distinct  referent genders related to the marking becomes obligatory in coordinated structure by juxtaposition: 'oj vo oj nake' (Ele e ela, He and she) (L. Bacelar, p.c. email from 13.01.2011).

Locative specification is done throught nominal compounding, e.g. 'table underside-LOC' 'under the table'. Specification of location is done by a nominal root involved in the compounding (S.Danielsen, p.c. 20.05.2010).
Clitics

A number of postpositions are enclitics, the other are independent phonological words. There is one Spanish preposition: hasta 'until, up to, as far as', except this borrowed morpheme there are no prepositions (cf. Guillaume 2008:77).
usipi o usipichu ; en la casa

The postpositions are of 2 classes: uninflected and inflected. 'Inflected postp-s take noun phrases as their objects, while uninflected postp-s take inflected postpositional phrases as their objects' (Morse & Maxwell 1999:134,135). The NP object of an inflected postposition is in the unmarked nom.case. If a personal pronoun is the object of an inflected postposition, the possessive adjective form is used (see example Morse & Maxwell 1999:136). There is a locative suffix -I (cf. Morse & Maxwell 1999:136)

NB: Smeets (2008:97) that number is obligatorily indicated in 1st and 2nd p. pronouns, but optional in 3rd.person. 3rd p.dual and plural forms can refer only to animate entities, for reference to more than inanimate entity only 3sg pronoun form can be used.
Number with personal pronouns is marked by the same suffix - naka which can be used on nouns to mark pluraliry (cf. CP&CC 2009:188)

Only in the set of polysyllabic personal pronouns, monosyllabic pro-s do not have the sg-pl distinction in 3rd person pronouns that are used for subordinate clauses for the same subjects (cf. Seifart 2005:55)
normal pluralmarking
The plural forms (of all pronouns except 1PL) are formed by the plural suffix -in added to singular personal pronouns. (1SG: ye, 1PL: tsin) (cf. Sakel 2003:93)
Dual and plural forms of personal pronouns contain dual and plural markers tse (from =ekatse 'DL') and kwana or na (for 3person) (from  =kwana 'PL') (cf. Guillaume 2008:78).
3rd person is expressed by demonstrative forms which can occur with the plural marker -kom to refer to plural entities (cf. Rose 2003:160,181).
Collective, not obligatory (see D79:127)
Only within animate 3rd p pronouns. Inanimate 3rd p pronouns do not distinguish number (cf. Dixon 2004:77)
NB: There are no special 3rd person pronoun forms, reference is made by demonstratives. Reference to 3rd person plural can be made by a particle wan 'and others' (cf. Seki 2000:62). Certainty: ?
Number distinction (sg/pl) is found in 1st and 2nd free personal pronouns; not certain whether 3rd p.p. have this disitnction. Certainty: ?
Number distinction is found only on pronouns in Awa Pit, nouns are not marked for number (cf. Curnow 1997:85)
Plural forms consists of 3sg + collective suffix -te (cf. Bacelar 2004:141).

comment: Plural marking on sg.form
Demonstratives, that distinguish number, are used as 3rd person pronouns

Historically 3rd p.pronoun was probably element a, nowadays it is not used in this function, 3rd person is left unmarked, whether singular or plural reference is meant. Therefore the Q answered as 'no number distinction'. Additionally, it can be mentioned that most personal pronouns in Matses (with exception of 2nd p. form mitso) cannot receive the plural/collective marker (-bo) which can be used on NPs to mark plurality. 'Personal pronouns are ambiguous with respect to plural vs. dual vs. singular, unless they occur with the pronoun-specific enclitic -ben 'alone/invain/for no reason', or one of the two quantitative postpositions dadi 'both of' or tedi 'all of' (cf. Fleck 2003:243). However, demonstrative forms can be used as 3 p pronouns, which can occur with plural marker if plurality has to specified. Distal demonstrative forms are highly probably related to the element a which historically served as a 3rd p. pronoun (cf. Fleck 2003:260).
3rd p. forms expressed by a demonstrative can optionally be marked for number. The plural suffix which is used with demonstratives is -awa (Grondona 1998:79).
Certainty: ?
there are no third person pronouns, demonstratives do the job, they may be marked for number

NB: There are no personal pronouns in Wari', there are only emphatic pronouns which may appear alone or in apposition to a noun in left dislocation, but may not appear alone as arguments of the verb (cf. Everett & Kern 1997:303,310). The emphatic pronouns have incl/excl distinction, gender distinction in 3rd person sg. and pl., and number distinction within all pronouns (sg/pl). The Q is answered for the emphatic pronouns.
The plural form of 3p.pronouns contains the collective marker -we?sj (cf. Jung 2008:132).
NB: 3p.pronouns are indicated by demonstratives, which occur with classifiers encoding number (cf. Vidal 2001:123)
Plural forms are formed by the plural marker -kuna (cf. Weber 1989:37)
pay-kuna
Plural personal pronouns are formed with the plural marker -kuna (which is used with nouns to mark plurality; with one exception though: 1pl pronoun is ukanchi and not uka-kuna) (cf. Cole 1982:128).
Plural is formed using the plural marker (this plural marker is prefixed to nouns, however it is suffixed to the pers.pronouns) (cf. Alves 2004:81).

comment: Sg/du/pl distinctions are made only animate forms of 3rd person, the inanamate forms have only sg/pl distinction. Dual is present otherwise in all persons (1st, 2nd, 3rd animate) (cf. Gmez 1990:49).
Plural is formed with 3 p.sg + the plural/collective marker -bo, which is also used on nouns.
Number distinction is made in 1st and 2nd person pronouns, but not in the 3rd (cf. Gonzlez 2005:121)
However, plural is not obligatory (Meira, p.c.)
The free personal pronouns have sg/pl forms, whereas verb can receive marking for dual form of the subject (cf. Olawsky 2006:213).
Plurality can be specified by the plural marker if plurality needs to be highlighted (Eberhard 2009:356).

Faust & Loos note that there is no 3rd person pronoun in Yaminahua. When an explicit reference to 3rd person is required, a demonstrative or a relative pronoun is used in that case (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:62). It is concluded from available examples that sg forms of demonstratives can refer to plural referents (e.g. example 302 on p. 65). Personal pronouns for 1st and 2nd person do have plural forms (cf. Faust & Loos 2002:62).
3rd p.pronouns are indicated by dem.pronouns; they take normal plural marker to mark sg vs pl distinction (cf. van Gijn 2006:129)

there is a restriction against inanimate transitive subjects.  These are realized as instrumentals (case markers homophonous) but another subject is included in the clause, e.g. 'Your nails cut me' = 'You cut me with your nails' ; or, the clause is treated as intransitive, e.g. 'The tree branch killed the boy' = 'The boy died with (from) the tree branch'.  The intransitive shift is clear from use of intransitive TMA morphology on the verb.  Ferreira p.c. 11-06-12

postposition ke can be used to add extra (adjunct) arguments to the verb that are not lexically specified. Semantically, this can have the effect of increasing the valency of the verb (by including a patientive argument), but the same strategy is used for a variety of argument types.  However, in cases where other postpositions can apply (e.g. goal/location), ke-marked arguments imply a more 'close relation to the verb'

The middle marker n-expresses affectedness of the subject as a semantic notion and is not expressedly a detransitivizer.  The factitive-inchoative marker -gat  detransitivizes transitive verbs  with O deletion or a reduction in transitivity (with an indefinite object interpretation, for example).  However, it also transitivizes intransitives.
